Text:
User: The ability to have a collaborative planning session or discovery session is the main reason I use the miro tool. It makes it easy for everyone to visually see the flow of data as well.
User: Miro makes complex discovery, planning, and process discussions into a simple, collaborative tool, allowing the full team to see and tell the same story. The use cases for Miro are endless whether you are in the Project, Product, or Engineering space, there are templates and activities at your fingertips aimed at collaboration.
User: Sometimes connecting shapes together is buggy and more difficult than it should be. I also wish there was a better way to connect Miro into powerpoint or another exported solution.
Summary: Users find Miro easy to use with helpful features for diagramming and appreciate its diverse templates that support various use cases, including project management and feedback gathering. However, they mention the lack of integration with other services like Notion and the absence of screen reading capabilities for visual accessibility, which prevents their organization from adopting it more widely.

Text:
User: üöÄ How to turn an ‚Äûalmost perfect‚Äù UI/UX to ‚Äûperfect‚Äù.
Using <STRICT_LINK> as a perfect example (created by @cnnr_cllhn) <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn LoseTheVery is a fantastic tool that finds a more ‚Äûconcise‚Äù adjective without using ‚Äûvery‚Äù. Example: very rich = affluent.
The core idea is simple and the UI was chosen to reflect that .It's straight to the point (just like the Google Search homepage). So what's the problem? <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn ‚ùå There are 3 main flaws:
1. Site feels messy
2. Design lacks consistency
3. Elements feel a little too cramped
We'll approach it ‚Äûvia negativa‚Äù style: by removing stuff rather than adding.
üë©üé® Let's work on that that using @figma
User: @cnnr_cllhn @figma 1Ô∏è‚É£: Decluttering üßπ
The most important step would be to remove the clutter ‚Äì the annoying newsletter popup, the newsletter section and the newsletter banner. We'll get back to it later.
This has already made a difference. The interface looks significantly cleaner. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn @figma 2Ô∏è‚É£: Let the design breathe üí®
Let's add more whitespace ‚Äì the more the better. This will achieve a better visual separation.
Now the `very + x = y` line instantly grabs our attention. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn @figma 3Ô∏è‚É£: Making buttons prettier üíÑ
Buttons look chaotic here: randomly spaced, different padding, etc.
Let's increase the font size, adjust the padding and replace the word ‚Äûrandom‚Äù with a dice icon. We'll also ‚Äûinvert‚Äù the third button.
The buttons now look modern and consistent. <STRICT_LINK>
Summary: User expresses optimism about AI's potential to enhance work, life, and creativity, and looks forward to a conversation at Figma's Config event. Another user requests a donation of 2 Bitcoin for a virtual collection.

User: This, on @figma makes no sense. Who decided rgba is the default color notation for css/web? Today we have so many color spaces available, but designers are stuck with hex/rgb. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @equinusocio @figma We've hit this a lot with our new design system. We use a lot of modern CSS but need fallbacks to represent things in Figma.
In the past browsers didn't keep up and couldn't accurately replicate designer's work. Now it's the design tools that are lagging.
User: @equinusocio @figma It's not a surprise when new features hit browsers - it's often gone through years of spec work and "Intent to ship" - I really wish @figma would step up here and be ready to ship things like oklch/oklab, color-mix, etc along side browsers

Text: User: Use it for just about anything. It would be cool if you could still work with maps. For example, as an alternative to the calendar or list view. It would be great to log a road trip, a travel diary or hikes and bike tours.
Summary: User finds Notion useful for various purposes, including working with maps, and suggests adding features such as calendar or list views for logging travel diaries and hikes. They also suggest adding a feature to log road trips.

Text: User: As a medical student, Notion has huge potential to organize my life. It has notes, calendar, tracker, and collaborative capabilities. I‚Äôm also enjoying the AI integration. I REALLY REALLY wish Notion would include the ability to hand write on iPad. I can guarantee the use of Notion by students would absolutely skyrocket. The other notes options all lack something, and if Notion allowed handwriting over PDF / lecture slides, Goodnotes, onenote and notability would all go out of business.
Summary: User finds Notion to be a useful tool for organizing their life as a medical student, especially appreciating its AI integration and collaborative capabilities. They suggest adding handwriting support for iPad and other note-taking apps, as well as adding more features to the existing options.

Text: User: Christ almighty, I just want to throw my phone out the window, as Notion is doing everything but what I‚Äôm pressing at on my screen. It‚Äôs not fluent and table management is awful.

Text:
User: In my organisation, I used Figma to collaborate internally with the design team and build creative content templates. This helped save the designer's bandwidth and dependency too. It also acted like a Design Repository for our internal team.
User: I love the intuitive UI/UX of the tool. It is also straightforward to use, drag and drop the design elements. A lot of ready-made templates make the work effective. It is a clean and smooth tool, I would like to say!
User: I am not sure, but I guess the only thing I miss is a step-by-step guide or tips. It would be great to get pop-up tips, as everyone using the software isn't a pro designer.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma's ease of use and custom plugins for designing different layouts, but they wish for more breakpoint options and full support for tokens and modes. They also find the animation feature glitchy, causing components to revert to their original state, particularly with buttons and hover animations.

Text: User: Notion is the best productivity app! I‚Äôm using it nearly a week and I‚Äôm flawless in my work! I use the To-Do feature a lot! I manage all my current projects with Notion! My life is so much easier and so much better! Thank you notion! God bless you! üôèüôèüôè
Summary: User praises Notion as the best productivity app, stating that it has helped them manage their work and projects effectively, making their life easier and better.

Text:

User: We use Miro for different verticals in our agency from information architecture creation to user experience workshops to process design. It has an amazing user interface, easy to learn, adapt and use for all level of users both for clients and colleagues.
User: Time to time when you use Chrome browser, you can have some level of performance issues on low level devices for large boards. It's rather a system issue then Miro issue but, performance optimization can be an agenda.
Summary: The user appreciates Figjam for enabling their fully distributed team to work on problems and create in real time together, with multiple people collaborating easily and quickly. They find it accessible even for those unfamiliar with design products. However, they suggest having more preset options to start from, although they acknowledge the large community.

Text:
User: Collaboration during brainstorming sessions used to be everyone looking at the same notepad as one individual writes notes. Now everyone is involved in brainstorming and setting up group activities is so easy in the app!
User: The speed at which workflows can be drawn when explaining the process on the board and how easy it is to set up a table and move columns and rows around. It's faster and sleeker than Microsoft competitors.
User: Sometimes when changing how my device is configured with screens/mouse/keyboard, the navigation around the board can change. For example, I use a tablet computer, and if I remove my mouse, then it changes for touchpad navigation. I feel like it could remain consistent in navigation unless I change it.
Summary: Users find FigJam easy to use for diagramming workflows and processes, and appreciate its seamless collaboration features for both internal and external stakeholders. However, they note some limitations in shape and color choices when building out flows.

Text:
User: It has helped us to execute our duties from anywhere remotely. This has made the collaboration between us to be more effective and efficient.
User: Miro offers a better and a great platform to work in especially in the Morden market. It centralises every file that I make,helping me to see all that I did at a glance. The fact that inviting others to collaborate is very simple and this has made me to involve my clients or colleagues, it has given tremendous results. The numerous and amazing templates on the dashboard gives me ideas and structure to my research. Things that I used to do on paper, or excel and other programs, I now do them on this application. 
The application's dashboard in real time let's us stay connected and I like that in graphic form. You can as well tag people with certain action items on your group.
User: Though its slightly expensive application,it's really worth it.
Summary: The user appreciates Figma as a one-stop-shop for designing, planning, and delivering leadership courses, with a nearly limitless toolset and intuitive functionality. They praise its team collaboration, content visualization, and presentation capabilities. However, they note a learning curve for new users and suggest board owners lock or hide items to prevent accidental changes. Some URL links also display inconsistently when pasted.

Text: User: Why can't I search like this? When I search to find what I've written, I can't find the first letter, and the middle is a strange letter. There's nothing I really want to see, so I've been searching for a while. If I have a problem, please let me know the solution~~
Summary: User is frustrated with the search function in Notion, as they cannot find the first letter of their text and the middle letter is a strange letter. They have been searching for a solution and would appreciate assistance.

Text:
User: Miro is a key success tool for making your meetings to runs smoothly and effeftively at any time. 
It has reduced time for manual meeting and cost in overall. 
The availabilitybof sharing capability has helped to finish project on time and track the projects effectively.
User: Miro is ine of the best collaboration in the market tool. It has great features and it's user interface is great and easily usable to almost every people in our field. 
It has available templates and it's sharing capability of files. 
I like how you can arrange and organise virtual meetings efficiently. 
The tool is cheap to everyone and i ts affordable.
User: To me there is no much to dislike about this tool itd the perfeft for the collaborstion work i have ever come across. I have gained a lot from it. It has shown good progress to my work place
Summary: The User is benefiting from the product by having an easier and more enjoyable collaboration and meeting experience, as well as gaining a better understanding of the overall project. The User enjoys the brainstorming templates and stickers available in the product, as well as the ability to follow another person's navigation. The User has no dislikes about the product, but they would appreciate the ability to find out who posted which sticker.

Text:

User: powerful collaboration mechanisms 
super easy to start, even for somebody with no experience 
range of templates available

Summary: The product is helping the User to collaborate with colleagues more easily when working remotely. The User likes that Miro makes it easy to share the progress of a research project in a novel way, as well as being useful to share findings and collaborate in group sessions. The User sometimes finds difficulty navigating and moving items around the board, as well as unintended arrows being drawn.

User: This, on @figma makes no sense. Who decided rgba is the default color notation for css/web? Today we have so many color spaces available, but designers are stuck with hex/rgb. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @equinusocio @figma We've hit this a lot with our new design system. We use a lot of modern CSS but need fallbacks to represent things in Figma.
In the past browsers didn't keep up and couldn't accurately replicate designer's work. Now it's the design tools that are lagging.
User: @equinusocio @figma It's not a surprise when new features hit browsers - it's often gone through years of spec work and "Intent to ship" - I really wish @figma would step up here and be ready to ship things like oklch/oklab, color-mix, etc along side browsers
User: @jacobrask @figma We also use oklch on our ds but we are forced to stay inside the rgb spectrum because of figma. Dunno but they seem more focused on the canvas feature now.
Summary: A user expresses optimism about AI's potential to enhance work, life, and creativity and looks forward to the discussion at Figma's Config event. They also discuss a series of posts related to Donald Trump and E. Jean Carroll, questioning the credibility of Carroll's claims and her alleged bias.

Text:
User: We benefit from solving process issues.. mapping current processes, generating ideas and reviewing target state processes. This has helped us visualise the problems regardless of region without having to be there personally.
User: Very user friendly. Not sure how I would have survived without this during the pandemic.. Since then, it has become a part of our daily work. We use this to collaborate between teams.. Share ideas, discuss and review ideas..
User: I find the licensing to be very tedious. My organisation has provisioned limited licenses.. so the others cannot edit the boards when they come to collaborate as they do not have licenses. So we are forced to use personal email accounts to create a free version of the board to collaborate and later transfer to paid version to use all the rich features.. 
 
This is very tedious and needs to be reviewed..
Summary: User appreciates the ease of collaboration and deployment of design files within their team, but finds the tool to be resource-intensive and sometimes eats up too much RAM.

Text:
User: It solves the same problem as other whiteboard app does. The fact it comes as part of Figma is a huge plus. I might consider using something else if it was a big add-on or wasn't part of the main platform. There are better apps, but the fact that this baked ina s part of Figma is the biggest reason I use it. It's great that it allows me to quickly spin up a board and hammer out visual concepts quickly and I'd happily use this to create UR artifacts, but it has some drawbacks and I wouldn't be able to facilitate some activities.
User: Figjam is a great tool that fulfills a lot of the functionality you get in more advanced whiteboard apps and does more or less a good job of it. The ability to deep-link to elements in a board, and make sections and post-its, is fine and works pretty well.
User: There could be more functionality to format and resize post-its. It'd also be really helpful, for the facilitation of workshop activities, to be able to show and hide sections. this would ideally be on a user or for users or user groups. More mechanics like this, which allows groups of participants and facilitators to work together, would have a positive impact on running workshop activity withing the Figma platform and in FigJam.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma for its collaborative features, time-saving templates, and ease of creating visually appealing charts and flows. They also enjoy using Miro for various agency tasks, such as information architecture creation and user experience workshops, due to its user-friendly interface. However, some users experience performance issues on low-end devices when using Chrome browser for large boards, suggesting potential room for performance optimization.

Text:
User: I need a fast, easy, and collaborative way to wireframe and fat-marker sketch ideas with my design and engineering team. We also use it for retrospective meeting whiteboards
User: I love that Figjam is in the Figma suite and is so simple and easy to use. As a Product Manager, I am not adept enough at Figma to use it as a whiteboard, so I use Figjam to mock up ideas and do light wireframing before turning ideas into designs in full Figma.
User: Figjam's strength is also its weakness- it is very simple and lacks some other whiteboard features found in competing whiteboard products like Miro. If they continue adding features, I think that Figjam will be a market leader soon.
Summary: User appreciates the searchable and editable document, as it allows for easy ideation and interactive meetings. They also appreciate the fast loading time and lack of archiving features.

Summary: The design team finds Figma easy to use, with good documentation and training available, allowing them to design user journeys and feature mocks efficiently. The tool's organization and sharing capabilities are appreciated. However, one user found it challenging to learn the controls for navigation and zooming, suggesting a potential improvement in user onboarding.

Text:
User: I‚Äôd like Figma links to open in the Mac desktop app, but they only open in the browser. The option to ‚ÄúOpen in App‚Äù doesn‚Äôt exist in my Preferences menu in Figma in either the browser or desktop app.
I‚Äôve tried reinstalling the app, reloading all tabs, and restarting my Mac ‚Äì‚Äì of the things recommended here:
 
 
 
 Figma Links Not Opening in Desktop App, Despite Setting Ask the community
 
 
 Anyone else having an issue opening Figma links in their desktop app? I‚Äôm using MacOS and trying both Chrome and Safari. 
The link does switch focus to the Desktop App, but it doesn‚Äôt open up to the linked file/page/frame. Turning the ‚ÄúOpen in Desktop‚Ä¶‚Äù setting off allows the link to open correctly, but in the browser.
 

User: Hey All!
I found out why there is no way to open any Figma link in Safari.
You need to enable only the ‚ÄúHide IP address from trackers‚Äù option in your Privacy settings.
Make sure to quit Safari completely and then reopen it.
image1042√ó246 48.3 KB
All the best,
Daniel
User: and, of course, if it doesn‚Äôt work you must click on the ‚ÄúOpen in Desktop App‚Äù when you‚Äôre link is open in restarted browser.
file-OoNIeh58Bs1114√ó1529 110 KB
Summary: A user is experiencing an annoying issue in Figma where they have to press a random numeric key or remove focus from a field before being able to enter a value manually. They have tried troubleshooting steps such as logging out and back in, clearing cache, and reinstalling the desktop app, but the issue persists. They are advised to submit a bug report to the support team.

Text:
User: I can analyse data in visual form really quickly on Miro - it really helps connect the dots when you can see all of the information in one space. it is also really helpful as a collaborative tool - i no longer have to be the single scribe, everyone can contribute actively during brainstorming and it really helps with getting open feedback from stakeholders which is not often easy to do verbally. i don't think i could be without miro especially in a remote working environment.
User: Working fully remotely, Miro is my most frequently used software because there is no other tool that lets me collaborate, ideate and present information across screens more easily than Miro. I can't say that i even miss physical brainstorming boards because i no longer have to transfer handwritten notes to a digital format - it saves so much time and nothing goes missing. it's really easy to track information and review past discussions because everything is captured digitally. all of the tools and templates are very handy, i don't have to think to much about how to structure information - it's plug and play and there's so much you can do. the interface is very intuitive.
User: Miro on ipad pro could be improved to leverage the capabilities of tablets. i use miro exclusively on my computer and hardly ever on the ipad because it is very buggy and takes too long to do what i would normally do on a computer. writing is fine but it's not enough for me to also use miro on my tablet - it's a shame but i guess Freeform is a good simple and free alternative. it would also be great if Miro could be used in offline mode with an option to sync once online.
Summary: User appreciates Figma's ease of use and helpful templates but faces challenges with navigation, specifically zooming in and out. They need a way to visualize processes, organize wireframes for presentations, and document software.

Text:
User: It solves the same problem as other whiteboard app does. The fact it comes as part of Figma is a huge plus. I might consider using something else if it was a big add-on or wasn't part of the main platform. There are better apps, but the fact that this baked ina s part of Figma is the biggest reason I use it. It's great that it allows me to quickly spin up a board and hammer out visual concepts quickly and I'd happily use this to create UR artifacts, but it has some drawbacks and I wouldn't be able to facilitate some activities.
User: Figjam is a great tool that fulfills a lot of the functionality you get in more advanced whiteboard apps and does more or less a good job of it. The ability to deep-link to elements in a board, and make sections and post-its, is fine and works pretty well.
User: There could be more functionality to format and resize post-its. It'd also be really helpful, for the facilitation of workshop activities, to be able to show and hide sections. this would ideally be on a user or for users or user groups. More mechanics like this, which allows groups of participants and facilitators to work together, would have a positive impact on running workshop activity withing the Figma platform and in FigJam.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma for its collaborative features, time-saving templates, and ease of creating visually appealing charts and flows. They also enjoy using Miro for various agency tasks, such as information architecture creation and user experience workshops, due to its user-friendly interface. However, some users experience performance issues on low-end devices when using Chrome browser for large boards, suggesting potential room for performance optimization.

I‚Äôd add info for each mock with detailed motion specs. This would help bring equal documentation to our Visual and Motion design.

Summary: User is benefiting from Miro's range of templates, diagrams, and sticky notes which make it easy to share complex ideas visually, resulting in improved collaboration and a more efficient workflow. The User finds Miro to be an incredibly powerful tool for collaborating with teams, due to its easy-to-use interface and real-time collaboration features. Additionally, the platform's extensive range of features are highly customizable, allowing for greater flexibility when working on projects. Users may find the pricing structure of Miro to be expensive for smaller teams or individuals, and the extensive range of features can be overwhelming for new users. However, Miro provides helpful support resources such as video tutorials and a user community to help users get up to speed quickly.

User: I think Miro is a very simple tool that comes between Designers and Non-designers to simply communicate through visuals rather than verbally speaking about it. With Miro, in my organization, everyone just simply hop on and draw something to visualize their ideas. I found this significantly helpful to communicate within a team.
User: Miro is the easiest tool to interact with. When it comes to bringing your idea to paper, Miro provides quick solutions such as a broad range of templates, which I like the most. I think for Designers like myself that work closely with POs, it's important to have a tool that both can use.
User: When it comes to organizing the boards, I find it sometimes difficult to find the specific board that I'm looking for. Maybe having the ability to folder the boards could be useful, but also inside boards, I wish I could organize my stuff more. Maybe something like Figma where you can have pages inside each board.
Summary: The user finds the virtual event tool interesting and interactive, making remote working easier and more engaging. They appreciate its flexibility and ease of use, but mention that it might be difficult for less tech-savvy participants to participate in meetings. They suggest adding a simple chat option in Miro to allow people to suggest additions.

User: I first came across it during an online course and fell in love with it! So I adopted it for my teams working from home. Now we are pretty much back in the office but its still my go to. I find it really aesthetically pleasing, which helps. and whatever I need, there is a template for it or something that can be tweaked.
User: The infinity of the boards is excellent - the templates, tools, colours, simplicity of navigation and its super intuitive so you don't have to learn loads of new stuff to use it! I love you can bring people to you - I love the tutorials. I love Miroverses....
User: When I have invited people to join my team, they inevitably love it and go off to create their own, which results in one of my boards being disabled to its a bit of a faff to sling them out of my team, copy the content to a new board and then get my board back. 
Also I really struggle with the % zoom. My boards have been built at 1% so when I copy and paste something in, its always so tiny that I have to locate a spec, and zoom in to highlight this to drag and enlarge. Its a massive pain! I dont know how to fix this now.
Summary: The user finds the Enterprise team management feature in Miro very helpful for understanding the challenges and benefits of Continuous Improvement Initiatives, such as real-time collaboration and avoiding business travel for workshops and meetings. Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
Summary: The user is enjoying the Arc browser and appreciates the new features, but is experiencing some lag when using it. They are also concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a desktop app for Windows. The user is also concerned about the lack of a desktop app for Windows and the lack of a mobile app for iOS.

Text:
User: Hi, I have an using when using the Figma.
When I disable the Chrome Hardware acceleration, I am able to open the Figma without any issue, albeit slower.
But when I enable the chrome hardware acceleration setting, everytime I open Figma, my browser will flicker once, and says that my browser did not support WEBGL.
Is there anyway to fix it?
I need to enable the hardware acceleration for other chrome features. But then I won‚Äôt be able to use Figma if I do so.
User: Hi @Tsasqa_Galih ,
Is this happening on a specific file or all the files?
If this is happening on a specific file, then it might be possible the file has reached its memory limits.
Figma is a browser-based app, which means it‚Äôs subjected to a 2GB available memory limit that applies to each browser tab, including those in our Desktop App. When loading or editing Figma files nears or exceeds this memory limit, it can cause performance issues like long load times or crashes.
I recommend you to:
Reduce the size of the file will usually help with load speed
Reduce the size of individual pages (for example by splitting a page into multiple pages) will usually help with rendering performance.
Hidden layers: loading and then hiding a large number of layers, especially in components or with images stored in them, can cause a high use of available memory on loading.
Stacked Masks and Effects like shadows and blurs also take a lot of memory to load.
You can find more tips in our Help Center article on how to Reduce memory usage in files that will help you to avoid hitting this limit again.
If you are still running into issues despite these workflows, you can reach out our support team so they can take a deeper a look into your issues here. Hope it helps!
User: Hi @Celine_Doan
It‚Äôs happening to all files actually.
Which is weird since i can still access all files without issue if i turned the browser hardware acceleration off.
i also tried using my other laptop with the hardware acceleration on to open all the files, and it does not have the same issue.
User: Hi @Tsasqa_Galih ,
Thank you for the details!
Can you also ensure WebGL is enabled in Google Chrome? The steps to do this are in this article: <STRICT_LINK>
If it is still doesn‚Äôt fix your issue, please reach out to the team by filling this form with all detail you recall (WEBGL issue, happening to all files, affecting browser and/or desktop etc): here
Our technical team can investigate further. Thank you!
User: thanks Celine. i followed the steps needed on the article and it still doesnt work.
but i‚Äôll fill the form you provided.
Cheers!

Text:
User: Hi all, I am working on a Figma plugin that needs to import style from our team library. Through research I think the way is to first use Figma REST API to get the keys of styles from our library file, and the use figma.importStyleByKeyAsync() to import the style. However, the issue is, this requires me to put my Access token in the plugin, and I don‚Äôt want to. Is there a way for plugin to authenticate when making REST API calls on behalf of the person who uses the plugin?
Or are there any other easier ways to import/access styles from team library file in plugin? Thanks a lot!!!
User: You have several ways:
Users will create their own personal access tokens, which will be inserted into the input field of your plugin.
Users will open the necessary library files, run the plugin there to get the necessary keys, return to another file to continue working.
Hardcode the keys in the plugin.
3.1. Or add these keys to, for example, a JSON file that you or anyone else can keep updating as needed.

User: Hi, thanks for the reply! I see, I will give option 3 a try, to hard code the keys in the plugin, and keep the plugin for internal use first. The other ways seem to have some extra steps for people who uses plugin.
Summary: Users are experiencing issues with Figma, where component instances do not update properly when there's a color change in main components. This issue can be temporarily fixed by changing the instance to a different variant and then reverting it back to its original form.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.

Text:
User: I'm not a big planner to begin with, probably due to my lack of enjoyment for more mainstream planners like Google calendar and traditional paper planners. Google (while claiming to be user-friendly) had too many tools and GUI's to navigate through which felt overwhelming to me, while still lacking the flexibility I desired. Paper planners I encountered in the store didn't do the job either because they were not formatted exactly how I wanted, and of course a regular old notebook didn't provide the online accessibility I wanted.
Notion is everything you wanted in a planner, and truly helped bring the planning side of me back to reality. It provided helpful templates I could use to give an overall format for what I wanted to write (checklists, boxes, etc.) which were incredibly customizable. The tool is simple yet powerful, without any unnecessary visual effects or special features you are forced to learn. I love that Notion can be accessed on any device via the website or app, and my plans look the exact same in any format without shifting its orientation or completely up-hauling the website layout. I would recommend this to anyone.
Summary: User finds Notion helpful for organizing their daily tasks and planning their week, as it provides templates and customizable tools for organizing their tasks. They appreciate the flexibility and ease of use, and find it helpful for their daily tasks.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
Summary: The user is a freelance writer and has been using Notion for a year. They are currently working on a book and are looking for a publisher. They are considering using a platform like BookBub to promote their book.

Text: User: Don‚Äôt subscribe through an in app purchase. Their product naming is misleading. The Personal Pro is their free offering with limited ai requests (20) but through an in app purchase they will gladly sell you the same product for a $47 annual subscription. Just like the free product it stops working at 20 ai requests. I‚Äôd say that this product without the ai feature is crap. You can do better with any number of free products on the market. Google docs, etc. And the product without the ai is free anyways so why offer an ‚Äúupgrade‚Äù link when all you are doing is paying for something they offer for free. I‚Äôm angry but glad I subscribed through Apple- there is a chance I can get a refund. The ai is pretty good but I am wary at the shady deal they tried to pull over me. Who know who else made the same mistake?
Summary: User is unhappy with the product name and misleading subscription pricing, as the free version is limited to 20 requests and stops working after 20. They also mention that the ai feature is not as good as other free products, and the upgrade link is misleading. They are considering a refund and are wary of other users making the same mistake.

Text:
User: The ability to have an interactive workshop online that is collaborative and impactful.
User: I love that you can collaborate with everyone at the same time truly. Building out the space for the collaboration is easy to do, allowing it to be prepared ahead of time. You can move between presentation mode and working mode quickly. Miro has made my workshops much more interactive. 
 
I love the built-in grouping and voting functionality. These provide a level of quick feedback you often to do receive in collaboration tools.
User: The number 1 item is don't count on everyone having received your invite to the board when you share. If you need someone in a meeting, you must have them validate prior that they have access. Often I have invited people, and then we have had to search for a way to get them in. I think this happens if they have an account already in place. 
 
There is also trouble with some of the functionality - you can Ctrl/V to paste but if you use the past from the menu often it doesn't work effectively... also things come in very small and you may have to go in search of where they were pasted.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma's FigJam as a highly collaborative tool with an easy-to-use interface, allowing for seamless teamwork through features like sticky notes and frames. They have no dislikes after using it for two years.

Summary: User is benefiting from Miro's range of templates, diagrams, and sticky notes which make it easy to share complex ideas visually, resulting in improved collaboration and a more efficient workflow. The User finds Miro to be an incredibly powerful tool for collaborating with teams, due to its easy-to-use interface and real-time collaboration features. Additionally, the platform's extensive range of features are highly customizable, allowing for greater flexibility when working on projects. Users may find the pricing structure of Miro to be expensive for smaller teams or individuals, and the extensive range of features can be overwhelming for new users. However, Miro provides helpful support resources such as video tutorials and a user community to help users get up to speed quickly.

Text: User: It's been over a month on the @browsercompany's Arc browser and hands down the best transition I have made in many years. A blog coming out sometime soon.
Summary: User is excited about the new features in the @browsercompany's Arc browser, including the ability to create a new tab with a custom URL and the ability to create a new tab with a custom background image.

Text:
User: When working remote as a product manager, it can be tricky to get everyone on the same page. FigJam allows everyone to share a single space, and it truly feels like you're in the room together. I have used it in situations as the sole driver while sharing my screen with the team to get a quick diagram or mind map put together, and I have also used it collaboratively with my team as a digital whiteboard. You can bring people into FigJam and have them collaborating within minutes whether they are familiar with the tech or not.
User: Being able to join with several colleagues, throw together a quick brainstorm and work quickly has been great! I have used FigJam professionally to lay out calendar schedules, run retros, and run client workshops. It is even valuable to go back to your data and organize everything into a visually consumable map. This is a personal note, but I even used FigJam with my wife (who at the time was on a job away from our home) to lay out our entire wedding floor plan and seating chart!
User: The templates can feel a little daunting, I often can't find *exactly* what I wanted or was looking for, but usually a quick search online or asking colleagues leads me to finding a better template. That, or I just go through and make my own layout because it's just that easy!
Summary: Users find Miro helpful for facilitating and documenting collaboration across their team, particularly in remote settings. However, some users find the tool difficult to use and believe it's best suited for real-time collaboration.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÅ Iterate, improve and grow. Be open to change and adapt to your audience's needs. Remember, building a business is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìà Track your progress and celebrate your wins! Set measurable goals, analyze your metrics, and appreciate your achievements. This is your journey and every small victory matters!
Summary: The user is a freelance writer and has been using Notion for a year. They are currently working on a book and are looking for a publisher. They are also looking for a designer to help with the cover.

Text:
User: Hi, I believe I‚Äôve exhausted all the existing help articles on this.
I‚Äôm having a hard time with something that should be very basic. I have 25 or so screens, the ONLY interaction between them is that the user should be able to click and/or press the arrow key to navigate LINEARLY between them.
Sometimes it works (especially if I go slowly, it works every time). But sometimes it doesn‚Äôt, sometimes it inexplicably jumps through sections (pretty much only happens if I press the arrow keys quickly). It appears that if I click through it goes linearly every time without skipping screens. So the problem is only with the arrow keys (which I can‚Äôt disable so I need to understand the behavior before handing off to my client).
I‚Äôve adjusted all the artboards. The desired order is Row 1 Left to Right, Row 2 Left to Right (as described in the documentation). All rows have the exact same Y coordinate. All columns have the exact same X coordinate.
I‚Äôve spent hours on this already and this is really basic behavior so I‚Äôm not sure why it‚Äôs so hard, I want it to act like powerpoint in presentation mode.
Any help is appreciated. I can‚Äôt really share the prototype because I‚Äôm on NDA.
User: Or up vote the solution here‚Ä¶
 
 
 
 Remove auto creating flow starting points Share an idea
 
 
 I love the new feature that allows multiple prototypes per page. One issue I‚Äôm having with it, is it assumes I want everything to be a new flow starting point each time I don‚Äôt link something from the first flow starting page. 
It has a very linear mindset. When I work/prototype I tend to work on a section, then link it back and that creates many flow starting points on accident and I have to delete them. 
It‚Äôd be nice if either - it only created the first one, and doesn‚Äôt assume you want many o‚Ä¶
Summary: User appreciates the ability to use images in new and cool ways.

User: This, on @figma makes no sense. Who decided rgba is the default color notation for css/web? Today we have so many color spaces available, but designers are stuck with hex/rgb. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @equinusocio @figma We've hit this a lot with our new design system. We use a lot of modern CSS but need fallbacks to represent things in Figma.
In the past browsers didn't keep up and couldn't accurately replicate designer's work. Now it's the design tools that are lagging.
User: @equinusocio @figma It's not a surprise when new features hit browsers - it's often gone through years of spec work and "Intent to ship" - I really wish @figma would step up here and be ready to ship things like oklch/oklab, color-mix, etc along side browsers
User: @jacobrask @figma We also use oklch on our ds but we are forced to stay inside the rgb spectrum because of figma. Dunno but they seem more focused on the canvas feature now.

Text:
User: Hi,
Today during UI class I have discovered an annyoing behavior. I tried to create a simple product card with a picture and a ‚ÄúSpecial offer‚Äù label placed inside the picture.
In order to reproduce the issue:
Step 1: Create a text field, turn it into Auto Layout and give it a fill color, just to create a label basically, like ‚ÄúFLASH SALE‚Äù etc‚Ä¶
Step 2: Add a rectangle and fill it with an image.
Step 3: Turn both into an Auto-Layout frame and try to adjust the label and the image so that the label sits inside. While doing so, you shall discover that the image covers the label and hides it, even when the label layer is above the image.
Despite that, when merging a text and an image into Auto-Layout and only then turning the text to Auto-Layout as well to give if a fill color - this method works perfectly fine, but at last both methods shall lead to the same result as far as I am concerned, so there might be a bug here. Or is it?
Thanks.
Summary: User faced an issue with a button not working after making changes in the preview. They provided a link to the issue and requested assistance.

Text:
User: Flexible platform for remote teams to work together on a visual level.
User: As a user of FigJam, I absolutely love the collaborative features of this tool. It's so easy to share my FigJam boards with team members and work together in real-time, no matter where we are located. The interface is also really intuitive and user-friendly, which makes it easy to get started with minimal training. Another thing I love about FigJam is its versatility - I can use it for everything from brainstorming ideas to creating wireframes and user flows.
User: It doesn't offer as many advanced design features as some other design tools on the market. While it's great for brainstorming and creating quick sketches or diagrams, it may not be the best choice for more complex design work.
Summary: Users prefer Miro over PowerPoint and virtual whiteboards due to its unrestricted format and ability to add extensive information. They find it particularly useful for project discovery, creating diagrams, and mindmaps. However, they struggle with formatting diagrams and find templates difficult to adapt.

Text:
User: 
Describe the problem your experiencing and how your idea helps solve this
When you create an autolayout frame, it always defaults to 10px. Many design systems call for an 8px grid and in many cases, users don‚Äôt want ANY padding especially where edge-to-edge designs are concerned.
Ask questions to bring the community into the conversation
What are everyone‚Äôs thoughts about the following solutions?:
Default autolayout padding based on the big nudge amount in your settings
Allow for tokenization of padding/margin grids and offer up autolayout parameters based upon those tokens
Allow users to override the padding to 0px at the creation of the autolayout frame by using an alternative key command like ctrl+shift+a (command on mac)

User: Fastest way I found to apply auto layout with 0 paddings: 
Select object ‚Üí option+cmd+G ‚Üí shift+A
User: Actually, even faster: Select object ‚Üí cmd+G ‚Üí shift+A
Summary: User experiences issues with Figma's scale tool, as it reverts the scaled component to its original size upon clicking the instance, and undoing does not fix the issue. They resort to using version history or resizing the original component as a workaround, and seek a solution to prevent this behavior.

User: Notion itself is powerful, but the app must get a low score! However, all functions cannot be operated on the app. For example, basic operations such as moving positions of some objects on the app are not possible! The interface usually gets stuck and is difficult to operate, and the compatibility is poor. If you don't want to do a more complete edit on the app, you'll die! Very poor experience of use! It's best to use it on a computer!
Also, sharing content from another place to Notion is very difficult to use. After sharing, you have to go back to Notion to do a bunch of operations and organization. This kind of basic requirement should be designed to be easy to use! I don't even understand that I shared a Youtube video to Notion. The result was to set up a page in Notion. Then the title was: What's the point of the URL?! It can't be designed. Can you create a page with the title of the video or go to an existing page and then create an embedded video??
Summary: User finds Notion powerful but finds the app difficult to use due to its poor interface and lack of basic functions. They also find it difficult to share content from other apps and find the title of the shared video to be confusing. The user suggests improving the app's interface and functionality, as well as creating a page with the title of the shared video.

Text: User: I have been using notion for the past two years and it is really helpful. I started using it to organise notes for uni and keep track of my assignments. Initially it is a bit difficult to navigate the service but the more you use it the more efficient you become. You can borrow free templates online if creating your own is difficult! I use notion to track almost everything and even without upgradation the app works reasonably well- you can access the basic things which for a beginner is good enough. Once i figure out how to create templates and deal with the more complex blocks they offer, I will definitely be upgrading to the plus ver
Summary: User has been using Notion for two years and finds it helpful for organizing notes for university and keeping track of assignments. Initially, it is difficult to navigate the service, but with practice, it becomes more efficient. The user appreciates the free templates available online and finds the basic features sufficient for a beginner.

User: I need a fast, easy, and collaborative way to wireframe and fat-marker sketch ideas with my design and engineering team. We also use it for retrospective meeting whiteboards
User: I love that Figjam is in the Figma suite and is so simple and easy to use. As a Product Manager, I am not adept enough at Figma to use it as a whiteboard, so I use Figjam to mock up ideas and do light wireframing before turning ideas into designs in full Figma.
User: Figjam's strength is also its weakness- it is very simple and lacks some other whiteboard features found in competing whiteboard products like Miro. If they continue adding features, I think that Figjam will be a market leader soon.
Summary: User appreciates the searchable and editable document, as it allows for easy ideation and interactive meetings. They also appreciate the fast loading time and lack of archiving features.

Text: User: I love Notion. I am yet to experience another app that allows to tailor your workspace right down to every single one of your needs. However there‚Äôs a big, big flaw in an otherwise nearly perfect app - reminders arrive silently. There‚Äôs no sound, no vibration. Neither on iPhone nor on the watch. So if you have to keep with lots of time sensitive and high priority notifications I‚Äôm afraid you‚Äôll either have to stick to some other app or combine Notion with your run of the mill reminders
Summary: User loves Notion but finds a big flaw in its reminders, as they arrive silently without any sound or vibration on iPhone or the watch. They suggest combining Notion with other apps for time-sensitive and high-priority notifications.

Text: User: This review is more about Notion itself than the app. After reviewing a bunch of other programs I subscribed to Notion to help build my new businesses internal infrastructure. I was happy at first but it seems that the moment anything goes wrong Notion support is less than helpful. I‚Äôve been going back and forth with Notion support trying to fix some billing issues (updating my payment details). Notion seems fairly incapable of actually troubleshooting the problem and at this point as I keep getting the same suggestions from different ‚Äòpeople‚Äô I‚Äôm convinced Notion help is running on AI and not an actual human with problem solving skills. Despite numerous occasions saying the system won‚Äôt let me update my payment details and suggesting an actual bug that may be causing the issues their reply was: It‚Äôs so easy, you don‚Äôt even have to log in. Please update your information with this link. Also to note, you only get a reply every 24 hours, so after every (it‚Äôs so simple update your info) communication gets a bit tiresome. If you‚Äôve seen Sh*+s creek this whole exchange was the equivalent of ‚Äújust fold in the cheese - what do you mean - it‚Äôs easy, you just fold in the cheese‚Äù. I‚Äôve tried to escalate this to a dept manager or someone in tech that would hopefully have the skills beyond ‚Äúit‚Äôs so easy just update your information‚Äù however the more frustrated I get the less inclined they seem to be to help me. It‚Äôs at the point where I‚Äôm considering switching to another service which will be a hard decision seeing as we have put a lot of time into building our systems in Notion. Also to note despite being told that the old payment info is incorrect and I cannot update my payment details they continue to attempt to bill the old card number and then send me warnings that I need to update my information. So, let this be a cautionary tale for anyone using Notion for their business - it‚Äôs good, until it‚Äôs not. At which point you better be able to problem solve on your own. Just fold in the cheese.
Summary: User is frustrated with Notion support, as they are unable to update their payment details and are being billed for the old card number. They are considering switching to another service due to the time and effort they have invested in building their internal infrastructure in Notion.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÅ Iterate, improve and grow. Be open to change and adapt to your audience's needs. Remember, building a business is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìà Track your progress and celebrate your wins! Set measurable goals, analyze your metrics, and appreciate your achievements. This is your journey and every small victory matters!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üåü Believe in yourself and your idea. As a solopreneur, self-confidence is crucial. Keep pushing forward, even when things get tough. You've got this!
Summary: The user is a freelance writer and has been using Notion for a year. They are currently working on a book and are looking for a publisher. They are also looking for a design team to work with on their book cover.

Text:
User: Making everything visual and allowing connection points helps team members see the larger picture. Having the ability to create high-level roadmaps helps to understand the strategy. Other tech options (MS Whiteboard, Excel, etc.) are available today but are not nearly as effective.
User: I truly enjoy the collaborative nature of Miro. The fact that everyone on my team can hop on and add content is super helpful. It allows me to understand better where people are coming from and lets me draw (literally) correlations between ideas.
User: One downside of using Miro is the licensing aspect. It would be great if there were a way to have a less expensive licensed option for business that doesn't allow for all of the bells and whistles. Many team members, for example, will stick to creating stickies and emojis and never use any templates or more advanced features.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's dynamic collaboration feature, which saves time by allowing simultaneous work on design and architecture. However, they express frustration with the inability to auto-arrange post-its evenly, especially within a box, and suggest improving this feature

Text:
User: I'm not a big planner to begin with, probably due to my lack of enjoyment for more mainstream planners like Google calendar and traditional paper planners. Google (while claiming to be user-friendly) had too many tools and GUI's to navigate through which felt overwhelming to me, while still lacking the flexibility I desired. Paper planners I encountered in the store didn't do the job either because they were not formatted exactly how I wanted, and of course a regular old notebook didn't provide the online accessibility I wanted.
Notion is everything you wanted in a planner, and truly helped bring the planning side of me back to reality. It provided helpful templates I could use to give an overall format for what I wanted to write (checklists, boxes, etc.) which were incredibly customizable. The tool is simple yet powerful, without any unnecessary visual effects or special features you are forced to learn. I love that Notion can be accessed on any device via the website or app, and my plans look the exact same in any format without shifting its orientation or completely up-hauling the website layout. I would recommend this to anyone.
Summary: User finds Notion helpful for organizing their daily tasks and planning their week, as it provides templates and customizable tools for organizing their tasks. They appreciate the flexibility and ease of use, and find it helpful for their daily tasks.

Text: User: I have been using notion for the past two years and it is really helpful. I started using it to organise notes for uni and keep track of my assignments. Initially it is a bit difficult to navigate the service but the more you use it the more efficient you become. You can borrow free templates online if creating your own is difficult! I use notion to track almost everything and even without upgradation the app works reasonably well- you can access the basic things which for a beginner is good enough. Once i figure out how to create templates and deal with the more complex blocks they offer, I will definitely be upgrading to the plus ver
Summary: User has been using Notion for two years and finds it helpful for organizing notes for university and keeping track of assignments. Initially, it is difficult to navigate the service, but with practice, it becomes more efficient. The user appreciates the free templates available online and finds the basic features sufficient for a beginner.

Summary: User finds the magic keyboard inconvenient due to block input (/) and mention (@) errors, which are not being addressed despite continuous feedback. They also find it difficult to switch to another program due to its collaboration features.

But when I enable the chrome hardware acceleration setting, everytime I open Figma, my browser will flicker once, and says that my browser did not support WEBGL.
Is there anyway to fix it?
I need to enable the hardware acceleration for other chrome features. But then I won‚Äôt be able to use Figma if I do so.
User: Hi @Tsasqa_Galih ,
Is this happening on a specific file or all the files?
If this is happening on a specific file, then it might be possible the file has reached its memory limits.
Figma is a browser-based app, which means it‚Äôs subjected to a 2GB available memory limit that applies to each browser tab, including those in our Desktop App. When loading or editing Figma files nears or exceeds this memory limit, it can cause performance issues like long load times or crashes.
I recommend you to:
Reduce the size of the file will usually help with load speed
Reduce the size of individual pages (for example by splitting a page into multiple pages) will usually help with rendering performance.
Hidden layers: loading and then hiding a large number of layers, especially in components or with images stored in them, can cause a high use of available memory on loading.
Stacked Masks and Effects like shadows and blurs also take a lot of memory to load.
You can find more tips in our Help Center article on how to Reduce memory usage in files that will help you to avoid hitting this limit again.
If you are still running into issues despite these workflows, you can reach out our support team so they can take a deeper a look into your issues here. Hope it helps!
User: Hi @Celine_Doan
It‚Äôs happening to all files actually.
Which is weird since i can still access all files without issue if i turned the browser hardware acceleration off.
i also tried using my other laptop with the hardware acceleration on to open all the files, and it does not have the same issue.
User: Hi @Tsasqa_Galih ,
Thank you for the details!
Can you also ensure WebGL is enabled in Google Chrome? The steps to do this are in this article: <STRICT_LINK>
If it is still doesn‚Äôt fix your issue, please reach out to the team by filling this form with all detail you recall (WEBGL issue, happening to all files, affecting browser and/or desktop etc): here
Our technical team can investigate further. Thank you!
User: thanks Celine. i followed the steps needed on the article and it still doesnt work.
but i‚Äôll fill the form you provided.
Cheers!

Text:
User: I'm not a big planner to begin with, probably due to my lack of enjoyment for more mainstream planners like Google calendar and traditional paper planners. Google (while claiming to be user-friendly) had too many tools and GUI's to navigate through which felt overwhelming to me, while still lacking the flexibility I desired. Paper planners I encountered in the store didn't do the job either because they were not formatted exactly how I wanted, and of course a regular old notebook didn't provide the online accessibility I wanted.
Notion is everything you wanted in a planner, and truly helped bring the planning side of me back to reality. It provided helpful templates I could use to give an overall format for what I wanted to write (checklists, boxes, etc.) which were incredibly customizable. The tool is simple yet powerful, without any unnecessary visual effects or special features you are forced to learn. I love that Notion can be accessed on any device via the website or app, and my plans look the exact same in any format without shifting its orientation or completely up-hauling the website layout. I would recommend this to anyone.
Summary: User finds Notion helpful for organizing their daily tasks and planning their week, as it provides templates and customizable tools for organizing their tasks. They appreciate the flexibility and ease of use, and find it helpful for their daily tasks.

Text:
User: I‚Äôve been a designer for a little over 13 years. Early in my design career, I started feeling like I wanted a more ‚Äòtechnical role‚Äô and switched to front-end development.
I remember the exact moment that the concept of components and systems thinking clicked for meüí°
User: At the time, I was building custom WordPress themes. 
Within my theme, I'd have a partials folder, full of my silly little components.
And I had my templates folder, full of my silly little templates.
User: Pulling components from my partials folder into my templates enabled me to have really modular, maintainable and organised template files.
Seeing it all come together was a huge a-ha moment for me, but I didn't know why ‚Äì¬†at the time, design systems wasn't a well-known concept.
User: I spent a tonne of time playing with Sass, extending classes, using mixins, and all that fun, CSS goodness.
‚úΩ
Looking back at it now, I realise that what I was really (kind of) doing, was implementing a simplified version of component properties.
User: Code felt natural and intuitive ‚Äì I loved the idea of having a bunch of components that I could pull from and iterate upon rapidly.
I wanted to be able to replicate that workflow in design so badly. But design tooling wasn't anywhere close to what it is now.
User: Designing in Photoshop involved a tonne of manual copying, pasting and replacing... The process felt outdated and ineffective, and often resulted in a tonne of inconsistencies.
I dreamed of a tool that could reflect some of what we do in code... even the tiniest bit.
User: When I learned about Figma a few years later, it felt like a huge weight had been lifted, and my passion for design exploded.
I'm so grateful to be working at a time where technology is evolving so rapidly, and some of the gaps between design/dev are starting to thin out.
User: This was a lot of tweets about nothing, but I woke up feeling so in love with my career. 
And just generally grateful that I get to sit around all day, working on design systems, architecting components, crafting design patterns and collaborating with developers. üòçü•∞ü•π
User: I don't think I'd be so passionate about my career if @figma didn't come around when it did üòç It's setting the standard of things to come, and we're only at the beginning. <STRICT_LINK>

However, the issue is, this requires me to put my Access token in the plugin, and I don‚Äôt want to. Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
