Text:
User: It replaced physical whiteboards for discovery and brainstorming sessions. It also works as an excellent ice-breaker and teambuilding tool to have everyone active during meetings or learning sessions.
User: For those who miss physical whiteboards and post-its this is the solution to easily (and virtually) visualize projects and organize brainstorming, project management and workflow visualization. It's very friendly, intuitive and compatible with other tools.
User: Some toolboxes usually overlap important information, and sharing options are not that easy to understand and use, mainly with external (not frequent) users.
Summary: Users find Miro to be an effective collaboration tool that helps run meetings smoothly, reduces manual work, and saves costs. They appreciate its user-friendly interface, available templates, sharing capabilities, and affordability. Miro has positively impacted their workplace, and they have no significant dislikes about the tool.

Text:
User: It's solving the problem of not being in the same room and is helping us solve the issue with misalignment, by providing a visual way to collaborate and align together in meetings.
User: The collaborative aspect and use case of Miro is great! I love how much flexibility you have with designing boards for various different scenarios! I love that you can have guest editors for boards without spending more.
User: I dislike that it can be buggy sometimes, we do run into issues where integrated apps like planning poker, causes issues. I also don't like some of the format constraints with Miro.
Summary: Users appreciate Figjam for its ease of collaboration with non-professionals, communication with product managers, and compatibility with Figma. They also enjoy the small widgets and meeting structure ideas provided. However, they suggest improvements such as background color customization, better connector line alignment, thumbnail setup, and more widgets.

Text:
User: Currently, when you test a prototype on a mobile device it will fit the prototype to the width of the testing device, despite the fact the zoom mode is called ‚ÄúFit to screen‚Äù or ‚Äúcontain‚Äù in the URL request param. Which results in a bad experience when the prototype is designed in a higher aspect ratio than the device you‚Äôre testing the prototype with. Main CTAs placed on the bottom of the screen will appear underneath the fold for example.
It would be ideal if you select ‚ÄúFit to screen‚Äù the artboards will actually fit the screen. So if the testing device has a less high aspect ratio than the artboard, space will be added to the sides of the prototype. And if the testing device has a higher aspect ratio than the artboard, space will be added to the top and bottom of the prototype.
The ‚ÄúFit width‚Äù zoom mode can be used for the current behavior.
User: This topic was automatically closed 90 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
Summary: The user is expressing their frustration with not being able to paste data from a spreadsheet into sticky notes, and is asking for help to resolve the issue as it is causing them to have to spend extra hours of work.

Text:
User: Notion would be amazing if if it was easy to do easy things. There is a lot of functionality that would make your life a lot easier. What takes away from all of this potential is a buggy and nagging experience trying to input information.
Trying to add a to-do list (checkbox) - click the Hamburger menu with your finger (iPad), list comes up, click ‚ÄúTo Do List‚Äù, menu goes away‚Ä¶ to do list item doesn‚Äôt populate. Try using touchpad, follow the same steps‚Ä¶. to do list doesn‚Äôt populate.
Create a bullet point, and click the hamburger menu, ‚Äúchange to..‚Äù, ‚Äúto do list‚Äù, to do list doesn‚Äôt populate.
You are also able to do slash commands. So I press ‚Äú/‚Äú. I see the menu open and it closes immediately. The to do list is only an example. There are endless nagging bugs like this throughout the experience. So instead of being able to use the app to enhance workflows and life in general, you are constantly fighting the app.
I stopped using Notion for about 8 months and used a number of other products. Because of all the data in notion and all of the ‚Äúthings‚Äù I had set up already, I came back to because SURELY they had fixed the bugs. It‚Äôs the exact same. No more consistent or stable than it was 8 months ago.
What is really annoying to me, is that they release new features. New and shiny things like their AI tool. I WOULD RATHER HAVE AN APP THAT WORKS PROPERLY and not have AI. I don‚Äôt care about AI. I just want to be able to input data. If that works, AI would be amazing.
It will be long and arduous, but i‚Äôm moving to ClickUp.
Summary: User finds Notion to be a great app for collaboration and brainstorming, but has experienced numerous bugs and glitches, including issues with adding checkboxes and creating to-do lists. They also mention that the app is slow and buggy, and the AI tool is not useful for their needs.

Text:
User: Tutorial Thread ‚ú®
Learn how to create this folded gradient effect with @figma, in just a few easy steps ‚Äî no plugins needed!
Ready? Let‚Äôs dive in üëá
#sponsored <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 1
Create a new artboard and add a rectangle with a grey fill <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 2
Go into vector edit mode and select 2 anchor points. Manipulate those till you get an angle you like <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 3
Repeat the first 2 steps and make sure to connect each begin of a fold with the end points of the previous one <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 4 <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 5
Time for some color! Create a linear gradient going from light to dark, and copy & paste the style to your vectors. (OPT+CMD+C -> OPT+CMD+V)
Tip: Use more than 2 color stops in your gradient for a unique look! <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 6
Nice! Now we just have to change the gradient angles for every other vector to create more realistic lighting <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 7
To take your gradient fold to the next level, introduce some extra color combinations! <STRICT_LINK>
User: Bonus Step
You can try to go for a top and bottom gradient effect as shown below... <STRICT_LINK>
User: Okay one more bonus step.
You can even try to split up a larger gradient in multiple stops to create an effect like shown below.
No matter what you do, make sure to experiment and have fun! <STRICT_LINK>
User: Are you trying out this technique? Make sure to share it by tagging @figma and @FonsMans.
See you at the next one!

User: Miro is serving as a place we can collect images, ideas and more from our clients in the architectural/interior design process. We can message them via Miro in order to keep communication and content in the same "space" throughout a project, and all team members can add to it and use it.
User: The interface is very intuitive, I rarely need to read the FAQ on how to use a tool or function. It is versatile in allowing many different tools to be used for visually communication information to clients/teammbmers. We use it in place of Pinterest boards/ style boards for our interior and architectural design services.
User: I sometimes wish the drawings tools were a bit more robust - they seems to be geared toward flow chart style communication. I'd like to be able to sketch free form shapes or have a larger shape library.
Summary: The user appreciates Figma and FigJam as a one-stop shop for design and mind mapping, praising its ease of use, stability, and reasonable cost. However, they suggest improving the sharing process, as team account users can currently add editors and charge licenses to the organization, with restrictions requiring an enterprise plan upgrade and increased cost.

Text:
User: Miro supports our team as a platform for digital collaboration -- it facilitates hybrid work, transitioning our information from the remote environment into the office and back.
User: Having worked in mixed creative, product, and engineering teams, I find Miro an effective tool for visual thinking and documentation. The tools are accessible for newcomers to adopt but scale well for power users to leverage templates and tools that adapt to content and user needs across a project or workflow's stages.
User: Whether at the board-level, or the team-level, it's up to individuals and their teams to manage board sprawl and keep things organized. Depending on the information guidelines of your organization, there may be some friction involved in ensuring that the right individuals are granted the correct level of access to certain types of content in a timely manner.
Summary: Users find Figma valuable for replacing physical whiteboards in discovery and brainstorming sessions, as well as for teambuilding and engagement during meetings. It is user-friendly, intuitive, and compatible with other tools. However, some users face challenges with overlapping toolboxes and sharing options, especially for external or infrequent users.

Text:
User: 1. It would be easier for all native Spanish speakers to use and understand: By having the interface and content in our native language, it would be easier for us to understand the application and use all its functions correctly.
2. It would increase our efficiency at work: By not having to constantly translate terms and concepts into Spanish, it would save us time and allow us to be more efficient at work.
3. We would feel more comfortable: If Spanish is our main language, it would be more comfortable for us to use the application in our native language.
4. It would allow us to learn new technical and business terms in Spanish: Using Notion in Spanish would allow us to learn new technical and business terms in our language, which can be especially useful if we are working in a Spanish-speaking business environment.
5. It would make us feel included and valued: By having the option to use Notion in Spanish, we feel included and valued as users of the application, which would increase our satisfaction and loyalty to it.
Summary: User suggests adding Spanish language support to Notion, as it would be easier for Spanish-speaking users to use and understand, increase efficiency at work, and make them feel more comfortable. They also suggest learning new technical and business terms in Spanish, which would be useful in a Spanish-speaking business environment.

User: This, on @figma makes no sense. Who decided rgba is the default color notation for css/web? Today we have so many color spaces available, but designers are stuck with hex/rgb. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @equinusocio @figma We've hit this a lot with our new design system. We use a lot of modern CSS but need fallbacks to represent things in Figma.

User: @equinusocio @figma It's not a surprise when new features hit browsers - it's often gone through years of spec work and "Intent to ship" - I really wish @figma would step up here and be ready to ship things like oklch/oklab, color-mix, etc along side browsers

User: I have a problem with the horizontal scroll of my prototype, it works perfect only if I don‚Äôt apply the dropshadow to the cards. I can‚Äôt figure out why, can anyone help me?
No dropshadow
With dropshadow
As you can see, the link with dropshadow, horizontal scroll works strange the initial position has a space and also the final‚Ä¶
thank you
User: @Raffaele_Parlato hey I also faced the same problem, and hours of researching I found the issue. Instead of applying dropshadow on every card individually, but instead group the cards together and then applying it as a whole. This should completely fix the problem.
User: @Raffaele_Parlato I‚Äôm not exactly sure what the issue is here with the scrolling, (I‚Äôm just guessing the system adds the shadow to the size of the cards) but I also found another problem with this which is the shadows actually overlap on one another (although it may not seem so, I used the colorpicker to test). but when you group them together, the shadows are always at the bottom and do not go over other cards.

User: If I apply a color style to an object as a fill (or stroke), I can‚Äôt apply any additional fills to that object. I also can‚Äôt change the opacity of that fill when it‚Äôs tied to a style.
Example: I have a button that is a frame with a blue background which is tied to a color style. I want to create a hover effect for that button by adding an additional 10% black fill on top of my blue color. Currently to accomplish this, I have to detach the blue from it‚Äôs color style, then add an additional fill black on top of it and reduce the 2nd fill‚Äôs opacity to 10%. See example screenshots below.
This not only breaks my blue color style, but if I have black as a style in my design system, I can‚Äôt use that color style either.
Has anyone found a workaround for this that I‚Äôm missing?

Text: User: I have been using notion for the past two years and it is really helpful. I started using it to organise notes for uni and keep track of my assignments. I use notion to track almost everything and even without upgradation the app works reasonably well- you can access the basic things which for a beginner is good enough. Once i figure out how to create templates and deal with the more complex blocks they offer, I will definitely be upgrading to the plus ver
Summary: User has been using Notion for two years and finds it helpful for organizing notes for university and keeping track of assignments. Initially, it is difficult to navigate the service, but with practice, it becomes more efficient. The user appreciates the free templates available online and finds the basic features sufficient for a beginner.

They appreciate its user-friendly interface, available templates, sharing capabilities, and affordability. Miro has positively impacted their workplace, and they have no significant dislikes about the tool.

Text:
User: Figjam has helped solve some of our collaboration problems with having a distributed and remote team. Brainstorming and collaboration meetings that previously were done in person in a meeting room with whiteboards are now done using Figjam.
User: Figjam is a great collaboration tool for brainstorming new ideas and recording different types of data in a consolidated space. It has been great in helping to discuss and plan large projects by providing a single place where all the different aspects of the project can be stored and shared.
User: There is actually very little that I dislike about Figjam. It serves its purpose very well.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma for its ability to develop processes in one place and share progress with colleagues and leadership, resulting in increased productivity. They find Miro intuitive, well-organized, and great for collaboration in hybrid environments, with visually appealing presentation tools. However, they suggest improvements in diagramming options, such as exporting diagrams directly to Visio or other flow tools for easier integration into external documentation.

Text: User: I really love the Notion app!!! Great app for enabling and enhancing productivity. Just a suggestion, it would be lovely to have a particular page or a particular note privatized by lock. This will help with people who have teams that are logged onto their notion app, and they want to keep some certain things private.
Summary: User loves the Notion app and finds it very helpful for enhancing productivity, but suggests adding a password or pin to a particular page or note to help with teams using the app. They also suggest adding a page or note to be private.

Text:
User: I really enjoy using notion for note taking and syncing between devices works flawlessly. Also lots of options to structure your notes, embed different components, create small databases for recipies and such etc.
There are a few flaws though: there is no offline mode, the AI features that I don‚Äòt use cannot be deactivated, is is not as fast as a native app like apple notes/simplenote/etc., there is no real pen-support for drawing and sketching, the app logs me out frequently and that feeling of ‚Äûhaving too many eggs in one basket‚Äú
One improvement that would be great: on iOS when I share a youtube video to a notion database via share sheet, the URL is the title. It would be great if the title was the video title and the URL was an embedded video in the content. Adding Tags when sharing would also be helpful.
Summary: User enjoys using Notion for note-taking and syncing between devices, but has issues with the lack of offline mode, AI features not being deactivated, and the app logging them out frequently. They suggest adding offline mode, pen support for drawing and sketching, and a better sharing experience for iOS users.

Text:
User: I'm not a big planner to begin with, probably due to my lack of enjoyment for more mainstream planners like Google calendar and traditional paper planners. Google (while claiming to be user-friendly) had too many tools and GUI's to navigate through which felt overwhelming to me, while still lacking the flexibility I desired. Paper planners I encountered in the store didn't do the job either because they were not formatted exactly how I wanted, and of course a regular old notebook didn't provide the online accessibility I wanted.
Notion is everything you wanted in a planner, and truly helped bring the planning side of me back to reality. It provided helpful templates I could use to give an overall format for what I wanted to write (checklists, boxes, etc.) which were incredibly customizable. The tool is simple yet powerful, without any unnecessary visual effects or special features you are forced to learn. I love that Notion can be accessed on any device via the website or app, and my plans look the exact same in any format without shifting its orientation or completely up-hauling the website layout. I would recommend this to anyone.
Summary: User finds Notion helpful for organizing their daily tasks and planning their week, as it provides templates and customizable tools for organizing their tasks. They appreciate the flexibility and ease of use, and find it helpful for their daily tasks.

Text:
User: I‚Äôve been a designer for a little over 13 years. Early in my design career, I started feeling like I wanted a more ‚Äòtechnical role‚Äô and switched to front-end development.
I remember the exact moment that the concept of components and systems thinking clicked for meüí°
User: At the time, I was building custom WordPress themes. 
Within my theme, I'd have a partials folder, full of my silly little components.
And I had my templates folder, full of my silly little templates.
User: Pulling components from my partials folder into my templates enabled me to have really modular, maintainable and organised template files.
Seeing it all come together was a huge a-ha moment for me, but I didn't know why ‚Äì¬†at the time, design systems wasn't a well-known concept.
User: I spent a tonne of time playing with Sass, extending classes, using mixins, and all that fun, CSS goodness.
‚úΩ
Looking back at it now, I realise that what I was really (kind of) doing, was implementing a simplified version of component properties.
User: Code felt natural and intuitive ‚Äì I loved the idea of having a bunch of components that I could pull from and iterate upon rapidly.
I wanted to be able to replicate that workflow in design so badly. But design tooling wasn't anywhere close to what it is now.
User: Designing in Photoshop involved a tonne of manual copying, pasting and replacing... The process felt outdated and ineffective, and often resulted in a tonne of inconsistencies.
I dreamed of a tool that could reflect some of what we do in code... even the tiniest bit.
User: When I learned about Figma a few years later, it felt like a huge weight had been lifted, and my passion for design exploded.
I'm so grateful to be working at a time where technology is evolving so rapidly, and some of the gaps between design/dev are starting to thin out.
User: This was a lot of tweets about nothing, but I woke up feeling so in love with my career. 
And just generally grateful that I get to sit around all day, working on design systems, architecting components, crafting design patterns and collaborating with developers. üòçü•∞ü•π
User: I don't think I'd be so passionate about my career if @figma didn't come around when it did üòç It's setting the standard of things to come, and we're only at the beginning. <STRICT_LINK>
Summary: The user has published a new version of the #pagger in the @figma community, which now allows users to assign tags, prevents the state of the pages from being shared between accounts, and allows users to test it as long as they want (not in the same file).

Text:
User: I really enjoy using notion for note taking and syncing between devices works flawlessly. Also lots of options to structure your notes, embed different components, create small databases for recipies and such etc.
There are a few flaws though: there is no offline mode, the AI features that I don‚Äòt use cannot be deactivated, is is not as fast as a native app like apple notes/simplenote/etc., there is no real pen-support for drawing and sketching, the app logs me out frequently and that feeling of ‚Äûhaving too many eggs in one basket‚Äú
One improvement that would be great: on iOS when I share a youtube video to a notion database via share sheet, the URL is the title. It would be great if the title was the video title and the URL was an embedded video in the content. Adding Tags when sharing would also be helpful.
Summary: User enjoys using Notion for note-taking and syncing between devices, but has issues with the lack of offline mode, AI features not being deactivated, and the app logging them out frequently. They suggest adding offline mode, pen support for drawing and sketching, and a better sharing experience for iOS users.

Text:
User: No-code tools for UI/UX Design!
As a professional in the field of UI/UX Design, you know that creating a great user experience is essential for any product or service. But, you also know that creating a great user experience can be a time-consuming and expensive process.
User: 1. Figma: Figma is a powerful no-code design tool that allows you to create, collaborate, and share designs with ease. It has a wide range of features and tools that make it perfect for UI/UX design. #UI #UX #UIUX #Design @Figma
<STRICT_LINK>
Summary: User is studying Figma and is watching YouTube videos on Envato, discussing UIUXDesigner, User Experience, UI, webdesigner, graphic designer, figma, YouTube, and Envato.

Text:
User: There is a lot of things it benefits me at work. It's a simpler design tool when compared to other Adobe tools. I can complete my task faster than using other tools. And sharing my work with other parties and communicating/commenting on my work is much easier when using Fimga.
User: There is a lot of features it's better than many other similar tools. But if I have to pick one, I think it must be the "Share" function. It's by default a web-based tool. Though it provides a desktop application, I mainly use the web version. Sharing my work with different parties is just never easier than before, owing to its web-based nature.
User: "PDF to Figma", it is a real problem for many designers. Currently, figma doesn't natively support drag & drop PDF into a design file. It needs a plugin to do that. Hopefully, we can have such native function soon.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma's ease of use and collaborative whiteboarding features, but some find it slow and sluggish at times.

User: Hi,
Today during UI class I have discovered an annyoing behavior. I tried to create a simple product card with a picture and a ‚ÄúSpecial offer‚Äù label placed inside the picture.
In order to reproduce the issue:
Step 1: Create a text field, turn it into Auto Layout and give it a fill color, just to create a label basically, like ‚ÄúFLASH SALE‚Äù etc‚Ä¶
Step 2: Add a rectangle and fill it with an image.
Step 3: Turn both into an Auto-Layout frame and try to adjust the label and the image so that the label sits inside. While doing so, you shall discover that the image covers the label and hides it, even when the label layer is above the image.
Despite that, when merging a text and an image into Auto-Layout and only then turning the text to Auto-Layout as well to give if a fill color - this method works perfectly fine, but at last both methods shall lead to the same result as far as I am concerned, so there might be a bug here. Or is it?
Thanks.
Summary: User faced an issue with a button not working after making changes in the preview. They provided a link to the issue and requested assistance.

Text:
User: I had a problem of trying to show someone the visual design that was in my head. By using figjam, and an add-on to download examples of designs, I was able to put together a mockup of a design to collaborate with my team and determine a solution that worked for us. The prototype feature meant I was then able to present our mockups to the CEO acting as a functional website. The presentation was a hit, and we got approval to move forward with the changes.
User: The amount of powerful features built into the free version is incredible. I'm using Figjam daily, from mockups of new websites to even simple UI designs to send to our engineering team. The ability to prototype a working design is amazing. There are some crazy good add-ons that you can use to extend the program for insane time-saving benefits.
User: It feels a bit overwhelming when you open it at first, and sometimes things may behave unexpectedly because you might not realise one of the settings is enabled e.g. clip content for a frame.
Summary: User appreciates Figma's real-time group collaboration and integration of Figjam files, but notes that non-design teams may find it difficult to understand.

Text: User: It's good
Summary: Nothing

Text:
User: Miro allows our distributed workforce to collaborate in real-time and keep an effective shared workspace that they can return to and use to continue developing ideas and opportunities. Also, the ability to adapt to the needs of each meeting and workshop are incredibly valuable.
User: The collaboration element of the board. The ongoing development and new features Miro continues to release. The diversity of exercises or workshops that can be hosted in Miro. The ability to enable hybrid or fully remote teams to collaborate effectively.
User: For people who have not yet used an online whiteboarding tool, the navigation and basic features might take a bit of getting used to. However, this can be overcome with some basic training or youtube videos.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's continuous development of new features, such as tags, sentiment-based clusters, and Miro AI, which help in organizing qualitative data for UX researchers. They enjoy the simple and intuitive interface, allowing for easy creation and organization of data from workshops. However, limitations in typography options hinder users from creating presentations that align with their company's identity, causing them to switch to other platforms.

Text:
User: I really enjoy using notion for note taking and syncing between devices works flawlessly. Also lots of options to structure your notes, embed different components, create small databases for recipies and such etc.
There are a few flaws though: there is no offline mode, the AI features that I don‚Äòt use cannot be deactivated, is is not as fast as a native app like apple notes/simplenote/etc., there is no real pen-support for drawing and sketching, the app logs me out frequently and that feeling of ‚Äûhaving too many eggs in one basket‚Äú
One improvement that would be great: on iOS when I share a youtube video to a notion database via share sheet, the URL is the title. It would be great if the title was the video title and the URL was an embedded video in the content. Adding Tags when sharing would also be helpful.
Summary: User enjoys using Notion for note-taking and syncing between devices, but has issues with the lack of offline mode, AI features not being deactivated, and the app logging them out frequently. They suggest adding offline mode, pen support for drawing and sketching, and a better sharing experience for iOS users.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.

Text:
User: It's a highly collaborative tool that doesn't feel formal; it's not a deck, but can be used to communicate the same information, and there are lots of fun stickers to spice up casual work sessions.
User: It's awesome that FigJam is built in with Figma and it's so highly collaborative. No need for a separate ecosystem. 
 
Love these product features: timer, spotlighting users to see their view of the screen, stickers, auto-align tools and guides, variety of community templates available.
User: Mindmaps are more difficult compared to competitors (ie, Miro). It's difficult to connect words into a cohesive web. 
 
When mood boarding and importing a bunch of images, it doesn't auto-resize photos into a neat masonry layout with consistent sizing like competitors (ie, Pinterest and InVision). 
 
Even though FigJam isn't for video calling, because it's so collaborative, I wish there was a chat feature like other online video call apps.
Summary: Users find Miro useful for collecting images, ideas, and communication in the architectural and interior design process, appreciating its intuitive interface and versatility. However, they wish for more robust drawing tools and a larger shape library for better free-form sketching capabilities.

Text:
User: The ability to have an interactive workshop online that is collaborative and impactful.
User: I love that you can collaborate with everyone at the same time truly. Building out the space for the collaboration is easy to do, allowing it to be prepared ahead of time. You can move between presentation mode and working mode quickly. Miro has made my workshops much more interactive. 
 
I love the built-in grouping and voting functionality. These provide a level of quick feedback you often to do receive in collaboration tools.
User: The number 1 item is don't count on everyone having received your invite to the board when you share. If you need someone in a meeting, you must have them validate prior that they have access. Often I have invited people, and then we have had to search for a way to get them in. I think this happens if they have an account already in place. 
 
There is also trouble with some of the functionality - you can Ctrl/V to paste but if you use the past from the menu often it doesn't work effectively... also things come in very small and you may have to go in search of where they were pasted.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma's FigJam as a highly collaborative tool with an easy-to-use interface, allowing for seamless teamwork through features like sticky notes and frames. They have no dislikes after using it for two years.

Text:
User: Notion is an absolutely fantastic app for projects, notes, sorting, and many many more due to its versatility and freedom. As a single person, notion is completely free with next to no restrictions. Teams will require payment, but it has a free trial to see how you like it, and I consider it fantastic for groups. However, that being said, mobile notion is severely lacking in certain features that the desktop version has. Basic features like renaming your workspace can only be done on desktop. There are also some bugs with the ui, like the back arrow sometimes just straight up sending me out of the current workspace, and the toolbar disappearing and requiring me to restart the app.
These don‚Äôt ruin the app by any means, as notion is still an amazing app and is still amazing in mobile, but I would consider mobile notion a great ADDITION to your desktop notion. Use desktop as your main form of using notion when creating, and use mobile when you‚Äôre away from the desktop or need to check something. Mobile as your only form of using notion isn‚Äôt terrible, but it‚Äôs definitely inferior.
Notion overall is an amazing app with amazing developers, who deserve lots of love and support. They also gave major generosity with the app, of which many other services would‚Äôve charged the individual a large amount of money to use what notion gives for free, which again is pretty much everything except very minor things like upload file size limits.
Summary: User praises Notion for its versatility and freedom, but notes that mobile version lacks certain features and has bugs. They suggest using desktop as the main form of using Notion, and mobile as an addition to it.

Text:
User: I need a fast, easy, and collaborative way to wireframe and fat-marker sketch ideas with my design and engineering team. We also use it for retrospective meeting whiteboards
User: I love that Figjam is in the Figma suite and is so simple and easy to use. As a Product Manager, I am not adept enough at Figma to use it as a whiteboard, so I use Figjam to mock up ideas and do light wireframing before turning ideas into designs in full Figma.
User: Figjam's strength is also its weakness- it is very simple and lacks some other whiteboard features found in competing whiteboard products like Miro. If they continue adding features, I think that Figjam will be a market leader soon.
Summary: User appreciates the searchable and editable document, as it allows for easy ideation and interactive meetings. They also appreciate the fast loading time and lack of archiving features.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.
User is excited about the new features in Arc Browser, including folder and tab categorization, and is looking forward to testing them.

Text:
User: Notion would be amazing if if it was easy to do easy things. There is a lot of functionality that would make your life a lot easier. What takes away from all of this potential is a buggy and nagging experience trying to input information.
Trying to add a to-do list (checkbox) - click the Hamburger menu with your finger (iPad), list comes up, click ‚ÄúTo Do List‚Äù, menu goes away‚Ä¶ to do list item doesn‚Äôt populate. Try using touchpad, follow the same steps‚Ä¶. to do list doesn‚Äôt populate.
Create a bullet point, and click the hamburger menu, ‚Äúchange to..‚Äù, ‚Äúto do list‚Äù, to do list doesn‚Äôt populate.
You are also able to do slash commands. So I press ‚Äú/‚Äú. I see the menu open and it closes immediately. The to do list is only an example. There are endless nagging bugs like this throughout the experience. So instead of being able to use the app to enhance workflows and life in general, you are constantly fighting the app.
I stopped using Notion for about 8 months and used a number of other products. Because of all the data in notion and all of the ‚Äúthings‚Äù I had set up already, I came back to because SURELY they had fixed the bugs. It‚Äôs the exact same. No more consistent or stable than it was 8 months ago.
What is really annoying to me, is that they release new features. New and shiny things like their AI tool. I WOULD RATHER HAVE AN APP THAT WORKS PROPERLY and not have AI. I don‚Äôt care about AI. I just want to be able to input data. If that works, AI would be amazing.
It will be long and arduous, but i‚Äôm moving to ClickUp.
Summary: User finds Notion to be a great app for collaboration and brainstorming, but has experienced numerous bugs and glitches, including issues with adding checkboxes and creating to-do lists. They also mention that the app is slow and buggy, and the AI tool is not useful for their needs.

User: Lack of visual communication: Traditional communication methods like emails or chats can sometimes make it difficult to convey complex ideas or visualize a concept. FigJam solves this problem by providing an easy-to-use whiteboarding tool that allows teams to quickly create visual representations of their ideas and share them with others.
User: FigJam is a collaborative online whiteboarding tool created by Figma that allows teams to work together in real-time to brainstorm, plan, and visualize ideas. One of the best things about FigJam is its ease of use and intuitive interface, which makes it simple for even non-designers to quickly create diagrams, flowcharts, wireframes, and other types of visual content.
User: sometimes UI could be complicated if you're a user that are not familiar with the FIGMA infinite canvas system (that you can scroll a lot and not find the end). Aside from that, is great

Text:
User: With Miro, we can brainstorm synchronously and asynchronously and further develop requirements over the entire project duration. The visualization makes the ideas clearer and easier to understand. This allows our developers to work in a more focused way.
User: Miro offers a wide range of templates. It easily creates nice looking diagrams that help you brainstorm and visualize requirements. The collaboration works really well.
User: Miro requires a good internet connection, other tools like Excalidraw are more lightweight. I miss hatched backgrounds.
Summary: Users find Miro easier to use for presentations compared to PowerPoint, appreciating its interactive and visually appealing features. However, they suggest adding filters or similar tools to improve navigation when dealing with large amounts of content on a single board.

Text:
User: Records for qualification learning are used with personal accounts so that records for qualification learning can be viewed on various devices, but anyway, shortcomings are conspicuous and difficult to use. I don't recommend it at all as an app when you want to watch content across multiple devices.
First, if you put in a lot of photos, character input becomes heavy. It's like a bad word processor from a year ago. Furthermore, when ‚Äú/‚Äù is inputted, it goes into command mode without permission, and it becomes like a freeze.
After adding AI to the function, even if you try to insert a photo with the insertion function (press + on the screen), it will prioritize AI character input, so it now takes about 1 minute to insert the photo. The addition of the AI function was a real inconvenience, and I can only think that it was added out of complacency. What's more, you can't disable the AI function yourself.
When I asked for a solution to such a complaint, I received a notification that ‚Äúthe AI function was disabled,‚Äù but it was not disabled at all, and they were left alone and unable to respond to inquiries.
Summary: User finds the app difficult to use due to its heavy character input and AI function, which takes too long to insert photos and prioritize AI character input. They also find it inconvenient that the AI function cannot be disabled.

User: As a Scrum Master I use Miro religiously for our retrospectives. Compared to other applications this has helped my team stay the most engaged, while also getting the most feedback from my teams.
User: I love the available templates that I can use on Miro. I generally use Miro for retrospectives and icebreakers that promote team building. It is intuitive, has many valuable integrations, and constantly adds new features.
User: All of the best features are locked by the pro version, which is understandable, but would be great to have a free trial. Also, dark mode would also be a nice feature!
Summary: Users find Miro ideal for collecting feedback on wireframe designs and collaborating with team members, as it is flexible, easy to use, and has intuitive keyboard shortcuts. However, it lacks BPMN symbols and swimlane structures, making it less suitable for process mapping compared to Visio.

User: Notion evangelist (?) It's an app that was recommended by friends around me while receiving rave reviews, but it's really not good to see the service these days.
If you get paid to do the service, please make it a little straight...
No matter how many times I delete and reinstall the app, the document doesn't open. (Infinite loading) It takes 3 to 4 times to open properly, and even then, if you turn off the app, it loads infinitely again...
Occasionally, I see this trend on PCs, but many difficult situations occur because they don't support offline mode. I think I should use a basic memo app or go back to Evernote. I don't think the saying that Guguan is a famous building came out of nowhere.
Summary: User is disappointed with Notion, as it is not as good as they expected and has issues with loading documents, especially when offline. They suggest using a basic memo app or going back to Evernote.

Text:
User: Miro is enabling a platform in which multiple users can consume content (created by teams) and contribute. 
I like all the features built to make that collaboration more efficient
User: I like the real time collaboration capabilities (value), I like the community aspect of Miro (e.g. free templates that speed up your work), I like the easiness and simplicity of the tool (usability)
User: I have mixed feelings about being a one-stop shop for everything a designer needs 
(PowerPoint, digital, whiteboard, design capabilities) and the fact the miro is not excelling in any of the areas. 
The highest benefit from the value proposition is the light-way collaboration aspect and how the tool is optimized for that (everyone can use it) 
At the same time, I appreciate some design capabilities, so I don't need to be jumping from tool to tool until all the concept is ready to be "migrated" to an execution tool (like Figma)
Summary: Users appreciate FigJam for hosting virtual design sprints and facilitating workshops, with diverse options for color schemes and fonts, and auto-naming sticky notes. However, they find some templates ordinary and wish for more robust voting capabilities.

User: Over the past 6 months, I've been on the hunt for a new browser that can replace Chrome for me as a writer and product engineer. And I found it...
<STRICT_LINK>
User: I was looking for 3 things from a new browser: privacy, performance and productivity. After testing the usual suspects like Firefox, Safari, and Brave and trying out some new kids like @KagiHQ's Orion, @SigmaOS, and @browsercompany's Arc - I eventually switched to...
User: @KagiHQ @SigmaOS @browsercompany Arc by the @browsercompany üéâ! You can read my full reasoning and review of all the browsers on my blog - but Arc has just completely stolen my heart ‚ù§Ô∏è.
User: @KagiHQ @SigmaOS @browsercompany As a writer, Arc's spaces and fullscreen workflow makes me feel so organized and focused when doing research; and as an engineer, it provides Chrome's dev tools with some added feature sugar that makes it a joy for development work.
Summary: User is using the browserCO app on their phone and is enjoying the experience.

Text: User: Don‚Äôt subscribe through an in app purchase. Their product naming is misleading. The Personal Pro is their free offering with limited ai requests (20) but through an in app purchase they will gladly sell you the same product for a $47 annual subscription. Just like the free product it stops working at 20 ai requests. I‚Äôd say that this product without the ai feature is crap. You can do better with any number of free products on the market. Google docs, etc. And the product without the ai is free anyways so why offer an ‚Äúupgrade‚Äù link when all you are doing is paying for something they offer for free. I‚Äôm angry but glad I subscribed through Apple- there is a chance I can get a refund. The ai is pretty good but I am wary at the shady deal they tried to pull over me. Who know who else made the same mistake?
Summary: User is unhappy with the product name and misleading subscription pricing, as the free version is limited to 20 requests and stops working after 20. They also mention that the ai feature is not as good as other free products, and the upgrade link is misleading. They are considering a refund and are wary of other users making the same mistake.

Text:
User: I use scale tool (K key) to scale design for mobile version.
When I literally click the instance of the nested scaled component it discards the scale and reverts the instance to the original size.
CMD + Z doesn‚Äôt change it back to the scaled version and the layout stays ‚Äúbroken‚Äù. So I have to use version history to revert everything back or as a work around I change size of the original component and it magically re-render the scaled instance and reverts it back until the next interaction.
How to stop Figma from this behavior?
Summary: Users discuss the issue of autolayout frames in Figma defaulting to 10px padding, which is not suitable for all design systems. They suggest solutions like basing default padding on the big nudge amount in settings, allowing tokenization of padding/margin grids, and using alternative key commands for 0px padding. Some users share their methods for applying auto layout with 0 padding quickly.

Text: User: They need to improve the phone interface and make it more intuitive. Too many clicks to be able to access a list or reminder. In addition to adding more languages.
Summary: User finds the phone interface to be clunky and inefficient, requiring multiple clicks to access lists and reminders, and suggests adding more languages to improve usability.

User is excited about the new Notion templates and mentions that they are a great addition to their design process. They also mention that they are using Notion for their personal and business projects.

Text: User: The app offers great templates to organize and structure yourself as a team as well as to set up your own personal area, which can be used to plan projects, goals or events. What is particularly cool is that the app combines everything you need and finally makes features such as task status, URL or links to established projects useful and easy. The system is intuitive - if you want to build something more complicated, it just takes a little longer at the beginning.
Summary: User finds the app intuitive and easy to use, especially for organizing and structuring projects and events, and appreciates the ability to combine features such as task status, URL, and links to established projects. However, they mention that it takes a little longer to build more complex features.

Text:
User: Miro provides an ideal software solution for collecting comments and feedback on wireframe designs, showing what they would look like with elements rearranged, and sharing them with others we are collaborating with. 
Team members can review content in their own time and leave post-it notes, comments and annotations with the flexibility to be able to draw, cut and paste etc. to get thoughts across. When we provide our feedback to others, it's very clear which part of the design each piece of feedback relates to and visually shows what we think it should look like.
User: Very flexible, easy to use, intuitive keyboard shortcuts for adding elements to the board make it quick to get thoughts down. Default colours and styles look good. 
Easier to navigate than visio.
User: Doesn't have BPMN symbols, and swimlane structure where space can easily be added in the middle of a diagram so not well suited for process mapping - I still use visio for that.
Summary: The user finds the Figma application intuitive and fast, with no cons to report. They have been using the program for 3 months without any complaints.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
Summary: The user is a freelance writer and has been using Notion for a year. They are currently working on a book and are looking for a publisher. They are considering using a platform like BookBub to promote their book.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
Summary: The user is enjoying the Arc browser and appreciates the new features, but is experiencing some lag when using it. They are also concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a desktop app for Windows. The user is also concerned about the lack of a desktop app for Windows and the lack of a mobile app for iOS.

Text: User: I have been using notion for the past two years and it is really helpful. I started using it to organise notes for uni and keep track of my assignments. I use notion to track almost everything and even without upgradation the app works reasonably well- you can access the basic things which for a beginner is good enough. Once i figure out how to create templates and deal with the more complex blocks they offer, I will definitely be upgrading to the plus ver
Summary: User has been using Notion for two years and finds it helpful for organizing notes for university and keeping track of assignments. Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.

Text:
User: FigJam is solving the problem of communicating about technical system layouts with people who are not accustomed to verbally processing such layouts.
User: FigJam makes creating diagrams and flowcharts very easy! In my job, I often need visual aids to explain technical systems, and I need to create those aids more or less on the fly. FigJam has been a lifesaver in that regard.
User: My only complaints about FigJam are very small, the biggest of which is that I wish it were simpler to create multiple wire attachment points on one side of a shape, using a snap-to-grid alignment. There are times when I need 4+ discrete wires running into one side of a shape, and I don't necessarily want them all going to the central point.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma's ability to facilitate brainstorming exercises with multiple people in various locations, making the idea-sharing process more fair and democratic. However, they find the UI challenging to navigate and struggle with the zooming and sizing features.

Text: User: Any want an invite to the @browsercompany new browser Arc? Have 5 here if anyone was interested to use it.
Summary: User is excited about the new browser CO, and is offering 5 invites for anyone interested in using it.

Text:
User: Miro gives a remote team a place to collaborate that is accessible on any device with internet access. It has become as fast as writing notes by hand, rather than the sometimes extensive start-up required on other platforms. Even rudimentary diagrams and sketches are easy to create in real-time. There is an opportunity to have asynchronous discourse through the comments.
User: It is extremely intuitive to get started as a new user. It has become an essential tool for remote collaboration on my team of primarily visual thinkers. It is easy to go from loose sticky note ideas to a full deliverable sketch (or even the final deliverable in some cases). The tool is so flexible we have had to apply some rigor as a team to use it consistently and get the most out of comments, notes, etc. 
 
I love that the Miro team is always pushing updates and new features. I also like the available training tools, templates, and frequent presentations hosted by Miro that feature Miro employees as well as outside users.
User: The dislikes are more about features I wish were included, such as better interoperability between Miro and Excel, as well as data visualization capabilities. I would like the ability to create vector symbols/shapes and add custom fonts. I also wish that there were more features that catered to printed media - such as the ability to create paragraph styles and formatting templates with labels that could be adjusted on an instance-basis, but still referred back to a primary layout.
Summary: User finds Figjam easy to use and flexible for their needs in aligning key initiatives and brainstorming sessions. However, they face challenges in granting access to others and occasionally experience functionality issues.

Text:

Text:
User: During workshops, I mainly use it to brainstorm all together or one after the other as a desynchronized tool when we can not meet all together. I encourage my team to input their ideas directly into Figjam and collaborate to organize the file as a comprehensive reference document for the future of the project.
User: Figjam is a powerful tool for enhancing collaboration and idea visualization. With its real-time collaboration feature and commenting system, teamwork becomes effortless. The file management system and template library are unparalleled among the competition, making it a standout option.
User: Multi account management and several workspaces can make the experience a bit difficult on the daily basis. I often find myself lost searching for my current workspace.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma's collaborative features, such as Figjam, which offers tools like whiteboards, mindmaps, and empathy mapping for efficient problem-solving. They also value the ability to comment on designs and receive feedback quickly. Figma is useful for UI design, prototyping, and testing, with powerful tools and community resources. However, the lack of offline functionality and a potentially steep learning curve for beginners are drawbacks.

Text:
User: Miro is solving many problems. Giving me a place to collaborate with others in a hybrid environment along with providing all the templates for a variety of work in one place allows me to use the tool to its fullest potential.
User: I like the dynamic templates for a variety of projects, screen sizing, ability to collaborate with peers in person or virtually, along with the ease of personalization.
User: There aren't too many downsides or dislikes that I've found. Perhaps the most annoying thing is the struggles that come from people working on the same page, but overall that can be mitigated by locking items so they don't get changed.
Summary: User appreciates FigJam for its ease of creating diagrams and flowcharts, especially for communicating technical systems. They wish it had a feature to create multiple wire attachment points on one side of a shape, using a snap-to-grid alignment.

Text:
User: It's helping us to work in hybrid envrionments and enables workshops to go ahead without everyone being physically present. Furthermore, we can make collaborative decisions more easily in innovation settings.
User: It's easy to learn and use for my colleagues and clients - frequently they can get started without any real training. I also like that it helps me think through problems easily without the bounds of paper and space.......it's available everywhere I have an internet connection.
User: I find that sharing with non -members could be easier. I also find the templates are harder to customise for your needs and that takes more time than it should.
Summary: The user prefers Miro over competitors due to its freeform tools, customization, and collaboration features. However, they face issues with text box limits, lack of automatic spell correction, and frequent new feature/update pop-ups.

Text: User: I have been using notion for the past two years and it is really helpful. I started using it to organise notes for uni and keep track of my assignments. Initially it is a bit difficult to navigate the service but the more you use it the more efficient you become. You can borrow free templates online if creating your own is difficult! I use notion to track almost everything and even without upgradation the app works reasonably well- you can access the basic things which for a beginner is good enough. Once i figure out how to create templates and deal with the more complex blocks they offer, I will definitely be upgrading to the plus ver
Summary: User has been using Notion for two years and finds it helpful for organizing notes for university and keeping track of assignments. Initially, it is difficult to navigate the service, but with practice, it becomes more efficient. The user appreciates the free templates available online and finds the basic features sufficient for a beginner.

Text:
User: Notion evangelist (?) It's an app that was recommended by friends around me while receiving rave reviews, but it's really not good to see the service these days.
If you get paid to do the service, please make it a little straight...
No matter how many times I delete and reinstall the app, the document doesn't open. (Infinite loading) It takes 3 to 4 times to open properly, and even then, if you turn off the app, it loads infinitely again...
Occasionally, I see this trend on PCs, but many difficult situations occur because they don't support offline mode. I think I should use a basic memo app or go back to Evernote. I don't think the saying that Guguan is a famous building came out of nowhere.
Summary: User is disappointed with Notion, as it is not as good as they expected and has issues with loading documents, especially when offline. They suggest using a basic memo app or going back to Evernote.

Text:
User: Notion would be amazing if if it was easy to do easy things. There is a lot of functionality that would make your life a lot easier. What takes away from all of this potential is a buggy and nagging experience trying to input information.
Trying to add a to-do list (checkbox) - click the Hamburger menu with your finger (iPad), list comes up, click ‚ÄúTo Do List‚Äù, menu goes away‚Ä¶ to do list item doesn‚Äôt populate. Try using touchpad, follow the same steps‚Ä¶. to do list doesn‚Äôt populate.
Create a bullet point, and click the hamburger menu, ‚Äúchange to..‚Äù, ‚Äúto do list‚Äù, to do list doesn‚Äôt populate.
You are also able to do slash commands. So I press ‚Äú/‚Äú. I see the menu open and it closes immediately. The to do list is only an example. There are endless nagging bugs like this throughout the experience. So instead of being able to use the app to enhance workflows and life in general, you are constantly fighting the app.
I stopped using Notion for about 8 months and used a number of other products. Because of all the data in notion and all of the ‚Äúthings‚Äù I had set up already, I came back to because SURELY they had fixed the bugs. It‚Äôs the exact same. No more consistent or stable than it was 8 months ago.
What is really annoying to me, is that they release new features. New and shiny things like their AI tool. I WOULD RATHER HAVE AN APP THAT WORKS PROPERLY and not have AI. I don‚Äôt care about AI. I just want to be able to input data. If that works, AI would be amazing.
It will be long and arduous, but i‚Äôm moving to ClickUp.
Summary: User finds Notion to be a great app for collaboration and brainstorming, but has experienced numerous bugs and glitches, including issues with adding checkboxes and creating to-do lists. They also mention that the app is slow and buggy, and the AI tool is not useful for their needs.
