Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.

Text:
User: It replaced physical whiteboards for discovery and brainstorming sessions. It also works as an excellent ice-breaker and teambuilding tool to have everyone active during meetings or learning sessions.
User: For those who miss physical whiteboards and post-its this is the solution to easily (and virtually) visualize projects and organize brainstorming, project management and workflow visualization. It's very friendly, intuitive and compatible with other tools.
User: Some toolboxes usually overlap important information, and sharing options are not that easy to understand and use, mainly with external (not frequent) users.
Summary: Users find Miro to be an effective collaboration tool that helps run meetings smoothly, reduces manual work, and saves costs. They appreciate its user-friendly interface, available templates, sharing capabilities, and affordability. Miro has positively impacted their workplace, and they have no significant dislikes about the tool.

Text:
User: Collaboration tools are very important in this remote world that we're living in. FigJam provides our teams with a "natural" medium to collaborate with. We love it for retrospectives, group plannings, brainstorming, etc.
User: FigJam makes it easy to collaborate with a team on a variety of different use cases. From whiteboarding, to retrospectives, to planning meetings, to organizing information.
User: Because it is mostly unstructured, you or your team is left to decide what structure works best for your use case.
Summary: The product is helping the User to quickly analyse large amounts of data, identify correlations and gain new insights, all within a visually appealing format. Users appreciate the product's simplicity and intuitiveness, as well as its unlimited whiteboard space which is great for collaboration, forming new ideas, and making insights. The User finds that the product can become clunky when uploading multiple files, and some PDFs are difficult to read. Additionally, the User has to continually log in to their work account if it has been inactive for a short while.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.

Text:
User: Collaboration as visual workers is the main problem being solved. I think it benefits to be able to zoom in so closely to media and also zoom out/organize info in lots of ways for lots of people.
User: Really love being able to follow along with users and what they're looking at. I also think the comments feature is really useful for pinpointing specific regions on a project.
User: I would love drawovers to maybe be a bit more intuitively designed. Sometimes it's hard to draw on the media on the board and moving the drawover and media underneath can be tricky.
Summary: Users appreciate FigJam as a one-stop shop for collaboration, especially in remote-first environments. They use it for various purposes, including ideation, flow mapping, and user research planning. Users also value the ongoing updates that improve usability, performance, and speed, but suggest additional customization options, such as background colors and styles.

Text:
User: Collaborative whiteboard. Ability to share thoughts on the fly wihout restriction and sharing our screenspace
User: Flexibility to add people into the project and no restriction of zoom in and zoom out. 
Also we can restrict who can and who can't. 
Ability to login using email from anywhere (multiple logins).
User: Need a bit more libraries/ packages to have bit more funkyier than what it is.
Summary: The product is helping users by providing easier collaboration for remote teams, as well as giving them oversight on work and the ability to document in a single location, which increases visibility and engagement amongst team members. Users appreciate the product's oversight for projects, its intuitive design, and its ability to integrate other apps and features. Users experience fatigue when zooming in and out, and find it difficult to create visuals and diagrams that are interactive. They also find it difficult to copy and paste elements from other sources into Miro, and wish they could consolidate their personal and work accounts.

Text:
User: FigJam is a valuable tool for my team and me. It allows us to efficiently produce low-fidelity wireframes, develop visual designs, and engage in collaborative ideation on a shared canvas.
User: FigJam makes it easy for multiple users to work together on the same canvas in real time, regardless of location. This helps the team conduct brainstorming sessions and ideate together for their tasks. 
Its intuitive interface helps easily create diagrams, flowcharts, mind maps and other required diagrams. 
Also, figmJam provide the integration facility with other Figma products and third-party applications like slack.
User: There is nothing to dislike in FigJam but something that I find odd FigJam is cursor chat feature.
Summary: User finds Figma easy to use, collaborative, and enjoyable, with good graphic integrations. They suggest adding more graph options for visual data analysis to improve the product further.

Text:
User: I really enjoy using notion for note taking and syncing between devices works flawlessly. Also lots of options to structure your notes, embed different components, create small databases for recipies and such etc.
There are a few flaws though: there is no offline mode, the AI features that I don‚Äòt use cannot be deactivated, is is not as fast as a native app like apple notes/simplenote/etc., there is no real pen-support for drawing and sketching, the app logs me out frequently and that feeling of ‚Äûhaving too many eggs in one basket‚Äú
One improvement that would be great: on iOS when I share a youtube video to a notion database via share sheet, the URL is the title. It would be great if the title was the video title and the URL was an embedded video in the content. Adding Tags when sharing would also be helpful.
Summary: User enjoys using Notion for note-taking and syncing between devices, but has issues with the lack of offline mode, AI features not being deactivated, and the app logging them out frequently. They suggest adding offline mode, pen support for drawing and sketching, and a better sharing experience for iOS users.

User: Our iOS developers rely on PDF export in order to grab assets for mobile development. Without being able to export PDF from slices, it requires additional and tedious workarounds for how to export assets.
I‚Äôd like to request PDF export from slices.
User: Its really a heartbreaker that exporting the slices to pdf is not available in Figma. Sketch has it and it was working really great for us.
Some of our multinational stakeholders, whom we cannot insist to install or start an account for Figma or anything else, as they rely on pdf documents for design review or sharing with internal team. Sketch helped to convert the slices to pdf which was very light weight and compressible. When we moved to figma, the internal team as well few clients worked well with figma collaboration (same we did with Sketch too) and but the later ones didn‚Äôt. And now we are forced to go back to Sketch, as we understand that its the app that we could rely to accomplish all our requirements.

Text:
User: This is my #1 choice of tool when collaborating with clients. My team uses Miro to document a strategy or wireframe and collect client feedback in real-time, it helps ensure the client that we are listening to their wants and needs. Instead of using a static PPT where we are just jotting down the notes, clients can see the work in action. In addition, we use the Miro board to document processes and attach key artifacts and URLS. This process documentation is exhaustive but Miro allows users to zoom in and out from a micro/macro view to learn about the process which is great for leadership to see and great for onboarding. It especially works for a global remote company where we can all jump in to review no matter the time zone. If you are in the same time zone, it works great to get everyone in the room and use as a collaboration tool. For example, I'm located in California and my client is located in the UK. We use miro to make updates on our timezone and get very detailed in specific areas of question. It allows for transparency, review, and collaboration.
User: In general, I like the whiteboarding and mapping capabilities that allow for deep thought, process documentation, and pure collaboration with teams. It allows me to jot my rough thoughts on paper where I then can find patterns and create a more solid process. Miro is the perfect think tank environment that you use from start (ideation) to a finish (a solid concept). It's also great for inviting colleagues for feedback or collaboration. Anyone can use it with a free license.
User: Miroboards have a size capacity where if you add too many screenshots, it starts to slow down. It can also get extremely messy and often confusing for a new user coming in and unsure where to start. Sometimes if you start your miroboard too big, the details of things like adding arrow connectors can be really tiny. Causing me to selecting all and sizing down my space so you can see these details. I sometimes run into issues with font formatting, if I copied and pasted a highlighted text in bold and then I drag in the text widget, it will copy what I've used when that is not my intention. It's really just the small details that I wish were fixed that could make my experience more easier.
Summary: The user appreciates Figma's ease in creating whiteboards for moodboards and presentations but finds it challenging to locate options for adding links or importing images and creating clipping masks.

In this picture I first scale then rotate, the points are transformed correctly, the rectangle and star are not. 
Here first I rotate then scale:
Here is skew. If that‚Äôs all I do, it works:
but as soon as I rotate the result, the objects and points do different things (the points are correct):
So, if I take an identity matrix and apply a bunch of transforms to it, how do I translate the final result to Figma objects?

Text:
User: 1. It would be easier for all native Spanish speakers to use and understand: By having the interface and content in our native language, it would be easier for us to understand the application and use all its functions correctly.
2. It would increase our efficiency at work: By not having to constantly translate terms and concepts into Spanish, it would save us time and allow us to be more efficient at work.
3. We would feel more comfortable: If Spanish is our main language, it would be more comfortable for us to use the application in our native language.
4. It would allow us to learn new technical and business terms in Spanish: Using Notion in Spanish would allow us to learn new technical and business terms in our language, which can be especially useful if we are working in a Spanish-speaking business environment.
5. It would make us feel included and valued: By having the option to use Notion in Spanish, we feel included and valued as users of the application, which would increase our satisfaction and loyalty to it.
Summary: User suggests adding Spanish language support to Notion, as it would be easier for Spanish-speaking users to use and understand, increase efficiency at work, and make them feel more comfortable. They also suggest learning new technical and business terms in Spanish, which would be useful in a Spanish-speaking business environment.

User: Hi. I‚Äôm new to Figma, and i‚Äôm currently struggling with this trouble.
So, I‚Äôm trying to recreate the www.pandaexpress.com website, and i‚Äôm with the banner part.
 
 
 <STRICT_LINK>
 
 
My steps are:
Create the base structure
Group it
Duplicate it
Adjust the circle and image for second asset
Make it interactive from prototype tab
Create a component set.
On the Design Frame, i add the component and it went crazy with the line that dragged into the previous asset frame. And when i present it, none of my clicks works with the banner. Ive cross checked the prototyped, and I‚Äôve selected the ‚Äúon click.‚Äù
Can anyone please correct me on which step did I do wrong?
Thankyou.
User: Only link the two variants together within the component. Don‚Äôt also link the component or any of its variants to the instance of that component.
User: Another thing might be the way you created the component. I‚Äôd make the two states first, then make them both components, then select them both and click ‚ÄúCombine as variants‚Äù in the right panel, then prototype the variants together within the component.
User: this solve my problem !!! thankyou very much !!

Text:
User: The ability to quickly collaborate on user flows and audit our product with non-designers has been made super quick with the use of FigJam. We are also utilizing FigJam for sprint retros, which allows other roles to become power users of FigJam, benefitting our team using the tool for different purposes and not having another learning curve.
User: I like the speed at which I can collaborate with my teammates for a variety of topics. I spend most of my time using the timer for timebox ceratin conversations around audit and design decisions which we use FigJam for. Additionally, creating user flows within FigJam has been tremendously helpful.
User: Currently, while components are available within FigJam, there isn't an easy way to visibly pull in the components without copying them over from a design file. Additionally, if I want to scale components I've copied into a FigJam, they can not be manipulated, and thus I spend more time jumping back and forth through files rather than having a focused conversation around review/feedback within FigJam.
Summary: The user finds Figma relatively user-friendly with a manageable learning curve and appreciates its ability to visually show ideas and thought processes using various mapping tools. However, they find it lacking in aligning formats for creating visually appealing or structured pictures and graphs, requiring manual adjustments.

Text:
User: Hi, I believe I‚Äôve exhausted all the existing help articles on this.
I‚Äôm having a hard time with something that should be very basic. I have 25 or so screens, the ONLY interaction between them is that the user should be able to click and/or press the arrow key to navigate LINEARLY between them.
Sometimes it works (especially if I go slowly, it works every time). But sometimes it doesn‚Äôt, sometimes it inexplicably jumps through sections (pretty much only happens if I press the arrow keys quickly). It appears that if I click through it goes linearly every time without skipping screens. So the problem is only with the arrow keys (which I can‚Äôt disable so I need to understand the behavior before handing off to my client).
I‚Äôve adjusted all the artboards. The desired order is Row 1 Left to Right, Row 2 Left to Right (as described in the documentation). All rows have the exact same Y coordinate. All columns have the exact same X coordinate.
I‚Äôve spent hours on this already and this is really basic behavior so I‚Äôm not sure why it‚Äôs so hard, I want it to act like powerpoint in presentation mode.
Any help is appreciated. I can‚Äôt really share the prototype because I‚Äôm on NDA.
User: Or up vote the solution here‚Ä¶
 
 
 
 Remove auto creating flow starting points Share an idea
 
 
 I love the new feature that allows multiple prototypes per page. One issue I‚Äôm having with it, is it assumes I want everything to be a new flow starting point each time I don‚Äôt link something from the first flow starting page. 
It has a very linear mindset. When I work/prototype I tend to work on a section, then link it back and that creates many flow starting points on accident and I have to delete them. 
It‚Äôd be nice if either - it only created the first one, and doesn‚Äôt assume you want many o‚Ä¶
Summary: User appreciates the ability to use images in new and cool ways.

Text:
User: Hi,
Today during UI class I have discovered an annyoing behavior. I tried to create a simple product card with a picture and a ‚ÄúSpecial offer‚Äù label placed inside the picture.
In order to reproduce the issue:
Step 1: Create a text field, turn it into Auto Layout and give it a fill color, just to create a label basically, like ‚ÄúFLASH SALE‚Äù etc‚Ä¶
Step 2: Add a rectangle and fill it with an image.
Step 3: Turn both into an Auto-Layout frame and try to adjust the label and the image so that the label sits inside. While doing so, you shall discover that the image covers the label and hides it, even when the label layer is above the image.
Despite that, when merging a text and an image into Auto-Layout and only then turning the text to Auto-Layout as well to give if a fill color - this method works perfectly fine, but at last both methods shall lead to the same result as far as I am concerned, so there might be a bug here. Or is it?
Thanks.
Summary: User faced an issue with a button not working after making changes in the preview. They provided a link to the issue and requested assistance.

Text:
User: I use scale tool (K key) to scale design for mobile version.
When I literally click the instance of the nested scaled component it discards the scale and reverts the instance to the original size.
CMD + Z doesn‚Äôt change it back to the scaled version and the layout stays ‚Äúbroken‚Äù. So I have to use version history to revert everything back or as a work around I change size of the original component and it magically re-render the scaled instance and reverts it back until the next interaction.
How to stop Figma from this behavior?
Summary: Users discuss the issue of autolayout frames in Figma defaulting to 10px padding, which is not suitable for all design systems. They suggest solutions like basing default padding on the big nudge amount in settings, allowing tokenization of padding/margin grids, and using alternative key commands for 0px padding. Some users share their methods for applying auto layout with 0 padding quickly.

Text: User: I have been using notion for the past two years and it is really helpful. I started using it to organise notes for uni and keep track of my assignments. Initially it is a bit difficult to navigate the service but the more you use it the more efficient you become. You can borrow free templates online if creating your own is difficult! I use notion to track almost everything and even without upgradation the app works reasonably well- you can access the basic things which for a beginner is good enough. Once i figure out how to create templates and deal with the more complex blocks they offer, I will definitely be upgrading to the plus ver
Summary: User has been using Notion for two years and finds it helpful for organizing notes for university and keeping track of assignments. Initially, it is difficult to navigate the service, but with practice, it becomes more efficient. The user appreciates the free templates available online and finds the basic features sufficient for a beginner.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.

Text:
User: I'm not a big planner to begin with, probably due to my lack of enjoyment for more mainstream planners like Google calendar and traditional paper planners. Google (while claiming to be user-friendly) had too many tools and GUI's to navigate through which felt overwhelming to me, while still lacking the flexibility I desired. Paper planners I encountered in the store didn't do the job either because they were not formatted exactly how I wanted, and of course a regular old notebook didn't provide the online accessibility I wanted.
Notion is everything you wanted in a planner, and truly helped bring the planning side of me back to reality. It provided helpful templates I could use to give an overall format for what I wanted to write (checklists, boxes, etc.) which were incredibly customizable. The tool is simple yet powerful, without any unnecessary visual effects or special features you are forced to learn. I love that Notion can be accessed on any device via the website or app, and my plans look the exact same in any format without shifting its orientation or completely up-hauling the website layout. I would recommend this to anyone.
Summary: User finds Notion helpful for organizing their daily tasks and planning their week, as it provides templates and customizable tools for organizing their tasks. They appreciate the flexibility and ease of use, and find it helpful for their daily tasks.

Text:
User: Miro allows multiple users to simultaneously share ideas as visuals within the same space without disruption. This feature makes it very helpful for any roadmap planning session. A team can always return to a Miro board after to recap what has been shared or continue the work.
User: I find Miro helpful in brainstorming sessions, prototyping new digital products, or mapping a flow chart. It is easy to share and export a Miro file to different formats.
User: I wouldn't say I like that there is no integration between Miro and Microsoft PowerPoint yet, and I believe many users have raised the same request. Since graphic and drawing tools on Miro are better, we want to have the ability to work between the two platforms to present any idea better.
Summary: Users find Miro valuable for enabling real-time collaboration among distributed teams and appreciate its adaptability for various meetings and workshops. They also like the continuous development of new features. However, some users may need basic training or resources to get accustomed to the navigation and features of the online whiteboarding tool.

Text:
User: Helps to visually explain complex systems in a simple way. Provides value to our consultancy.
User: FigJam's simplicity and ease of use enables fast mapping and sharing of complex systems and dependencies. I've recently created several sprawling figjam charts that outline marketing programs from beginning to end for our clients. They have been so helpful keeping the team informed at a high level and are a great reference to regularly huddle around. 
 
This is just one kind of use - because of its flexibility you can begin to discover ways to think and present ideas large or small. Create fast design mock-ups, review and provide feedback on designs, create storyboards - the list can go on and on. Easily shareable to anyone with little to no trouble with login attempts or dealing with incompatible file types. 
 
It feels so freeing to break from the clunky confines of a ppt slide with its bad clip art and boring bullet points. Expanding across an endless canvas allows us to combat any confusion or anxiety that tends to show up around building complex marketing campaigns. 
 
Figjam has become one the most valuable tools in my arsenal and is one of the best I've seen after almost 2 decades of working with these types of apps. 
 
Highly recommended!
User: Can't think of any at the moment. I need to spend more time exploring all the templates to expand my usage.
Summary: Users find Figma easy to use for collaboration between design and development teams, and appreciate its features for creating design systems, libraries, and reusable projects. They suggest adding tutorials and help guidelines for further assistance.

Text:
User: With Miro we can now use one system with endless space to build upon. We dont run into space issues anymore and everyone can easily access and edit it, whereas before that was more difficult.
User: I am a merchant who uses Miro to collaborate with design when building our seasonal assortment. I love how intuitive and visual it is.
User: It has difficulty loading once the boards are built. I create and build on lots of boards, but it needs to be able to withstand lots of boards and images to be a collaborative visual platform.
Summary: The user finds Miro excellent for facilitating collaboration during workshops and team-based activities, praising its real-time collaboration capabilities, wide range of tools and templates, and rich media integration. However, they experience performance issues with large boards or many simultaneous users and feel that customization options can be restrictive.

Text: User: I really think this app is great for everything. The only problem I have is when you have too many workspaces then you have to pay up.
Summary: User finds the app great for organizing their work, but mentions the need to pay for additional workspaces if they have too many open.

Text:
User: It has provided a platform for us to collaborate and convey our ideas more creatively; from a productive perspective, it saves teams time as people can continually chime in and add to a board at any point during their day; we don't all have to be present or working on it together for it to work.
User: I like the group collaboration features; I think it is fantastic how everyone can get into working on an idea all at once; being a visual tool also helps; I think it's great.
User: If I were to mention something, it would be getting used to moving around the boards; it's a slightly different mindset; it's not a showstopper but a slight twist.
Summary: Users find Miro to be a collaborative and user-friendly tool with helpful templates and community support. However, they face challenges in locating work on the canvas due to varying zoom levels and placement by team members. They suggest marking the center of the canvas and starting at 100% zoom for consistency.

Summary: Users appreciate Miro for collaboration and personal project planning, as it consolidates multiple tools into one platform. However, finding the right template can be challenging, requiring users to try multiple options before settling on one.

Text:
User: We needed a tool to effectively whiteboard remotely and to retain the information in an easily accessible channel.
User: Miro has replaced our in-person white-boarding sessions with easy-to-use options for our marketing teams. Non-technical users pick up on the post-it style boards super quick, allowing what used to be meetings in the office to be very productive regardless of where our staff is located.
User: For new users, Miro can be overwhelming at first. Otherwise, it's been hard to think of anything that jumps out as needing improvement.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its usability, flexibility, and powerful tools like sticky notes, mapping, and brainstorming. It is suitable for remote teams and supports multiple devices. However, some users face challenges with navigation, particularly when zooming in and out or browsing boards with a lot of content.

And within the plugin/widget icon, my settings keep going to ‚ÄòRecents‚Äô which only have a ‚ÄòRun‚Äô option.
Only using the plugin/widget icon, then changing the dropdown to ‚ÄòInstalled‚Äô then the 3-dot kabob menu seems like the only way. And it‚Äôs very difficult to find!
Bring back Manage Plugins or Uninstall at a more easily viewed level, like in the Plugins actions or master Figma actions please!

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÅ Iterate, improve and grow. Be open to change and adapt to your audience's needs. Remember, building a business is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìà Track your progress and celebrate your wins! Set measurable goals, analyze your metrics, and appreciate your achievements. This is your journey and every small victory matters!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üåü Believe in yourself and your idea. As a solopreneur, self-confidence is crucial. Keep pushing forward, even when things get tough. You've got this!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÑ Found this thread helpful? Share it with fellow indie makers and solopreneurs who could use these tips! Let's support each other on our solo business journeys!<STRICT_LINK>
Summary: The user is a freelance writer and has been using Notion for a few months. They are currently working on a project and are looking for a designer to join their team.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
Summary: The user is enjoying the Arc browser and appreciates the new features, but is experiencing some lag when using it. They are also concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a desktop app for Windows. The user is also concerned about the lack of a desktop app for Windows and the lack of a mobile app for iOS.

Text:
User: Everyone: "Use @googledocs it's simple ‚Äì No use @evernote and @NotionHQ it's shared ‚Äì No do @RoamResearch it's serious ‚Äì No, use Apple Notes and Google Keep..."
Me: They ALL run INSIDE my @obsdmd ü§£üòé ü§Ø
Be a rebel üëá <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd Obsidian is built on a technology called "Electron".
Electron is just a Chrome browser, that runs like an app on your desktop.
So essentially Obsidian = Snazzy Browser for your notes.
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd This allows us - in theory - to browse any website.
(In practice it works 80% of the time, hence I couldn't get it to work with @tana_inc or @logseq )
While Obsidian does not support that out of the box - with a plugin it's easy. Let's get to it!
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Go to Settings > Community Plugins. Search for "Custom Frames"
Install it. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq In the Obsidian settings there will be now a new entry "Custom Frames" (towards end of your list)
Find the "New Frame" button and click it. A Frame is such a browser window, that we can use to access all of the services.
The new entry will appear in the list above the button. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Configure your Frame
1 Set the URL (<STRICT_LINK>, <STRICT_LINK> or <STRICT_LINK> - copy & paste from Browser)
2 ‚úÖ "open in center" to open the service like a tab (otherwise it's in the sidebar)
3 ‚úÖ "Add Ribbon Icon" to display a side icon. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Specify the icon you want to use.
Go to <STRICT_LINK> and find an icon you like.
Copy paste it's name into the "icon" textfield in previous step. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq RESTART OBSIDIAN
Your new ribbon icon should now appear on the left.
You will have to log in to Google/Apple/Evernote/... the first time. But then it will remember you. (Just like in a browser)

Text:
User: We‚Äôre working on a larger Component library that includes non-published components (components with the prefix _ or .) as base components in order to simplify large, complex components. We intended ‚Äì in some specific cases ‚Äì to offer regular components as templates, that a designer would then have to detach and work with a bunch of base components to build the desired design.
What we have come to realize with this approach, however, is that these non-published components don‚Äôt receive updates from the library when they are updated in the main library.
Is this intended behaviour?
We basically have the option to simply publish these base components as regular components, but that of course would mean cluttering up the assets overview with a bunch of modular components.
User: hi, Raphael. our team is also facing the same issue for a while. Have you or your team figured out the workaround for this issue? I wish Figma can solve this issue fundamentally. @Josh thank you

Text:
User: I really enjoy using notion for note taking and syncing between devices works flawlessly. Also lots of options to structure your notes, embed different components, create small databases for recipies and such etc.
There are a few flaws though: there is no offline mode, the AI features that I don‚Äòt use cannot be deactivated, is is not as fast as a native app like apple notes/simplenote/etc., there is no real pen-support for drawing and sketching, the app logs me out frequently and that feeling of ‚Äûhaving too many eggs in one basket‚Äú
One improvement that would be great: on iOS when I share a youtube video to a notion database via share sheet, the URL is the title. It would be great if the title was the video title and the URL was an embedded video in the content. Adding Tags when sharing would also be helpful.
Summary: User enjoys using Notion for note-taking and syncing between devices, but has issues with the lack of offline mode, AI features not being deactivated, and the app logging them out frequently. They suggest adding offline mode, pen support for drawing and sketching, and a better sharing experience for iOS users.

Text: User: Don‚Äôt subscribe through an in app purchase. Their product naming is misleading. The Personal Pro is their free offering with limited ai requests (20) but through an in app purchase they will gladly sell you the same product for a $47 annual subscription. Just like the free product it stops working at 20 ai requests. I‚Äôd say that this product without the ai feature is crap. You can do better with any number of free products on the market. Google docs, etc. And the product without the ai is free anyways so why offer an ‚Äúupgrade‚Äù link when all you are doing is paying for something they offer for free. I‚Äôm angry but glad I subscribed through Apple- there is a chance I can get a refund. The ai is pretty good but I am wary at the shady deal they tried to pull over me. Who know who else made the same mistake?
Summary: User is unhappy with the product name and misleading subscription pricing, as the free version is limited to 20 requests and stops working after 20. They also mention that the ai feature is not as good as other free products, and the upgrade link is misleading. They are considering a refund and are wary of other users making the same mistake.

Text:
User: I use it for several things: private documents to guide my thinking and notes; collaborative whiteboards; sharing diagrams with colleagues; and documentation.
User: As far as I'm aware, Miro is unique in its ability to enable a user to rapidly build diagrams in real-time while other users observe or contribute simultaneously. I can create flow charts and diagrams so quickly. And it's easy to make the results look great.
User: The tables feature is lackluster, but it's still an experiment. Other than that, the licensing model has been slightly annoying to deal with. If I want a colleague to contribute to a board, they need a full license, even if they use it for 30 minutes and never use it again. This arrangement doesn't feel optimal from a fairness and value point-of-view, but I still find the tool to be worth the money.
Summary: The user finds Figma helpful for designing and creating diagrams, making requirements easily understandable for developers and testers. However, they face an issue with different UI versions getting minimized and reflecting other versions when maximized.

They enjoy the ease of use, interactivity, and templates compared to PowerPoint. However, some users find certain tools, like frames and form manipulation, complex and challenging to use. Additionally, they experience occasional slow loading times, but the cause is unclear.

Text: User: It was good at first. However, fees increased by adopting unnecessary AI. I want you to stop rushing into things you don't need and making them expensive. I'm not satisfied with this ‚ë†. Dissatisfied ‚ë° is that you can't change (break) steps with the smartphone app. Note is designed to be entered for each WordPress-like paragraph (paragraph), but a break is not possible with a smartphone application. On a PC, you can do it by holding down the Shift key. Dissatisfaction ‚ë¢ is that the margin and padding for each paragraph when the steps are broken are narrow. Even though it's every paragraph, even if the characters are embedded so harshly. In the end, a paragraph with an empty line will be added. If these are improved, I'll gladly continue using it for a fee. I wonder if engineers aren't very particular people. Unlikely ‚Üí postscript. It's too much of a mystery that you can't sort the top positions on a smartphone.
Summary: User is dissatisfied with the increased fees for adopting unnecessary AI features and the inability to break steps in the smartphone app. They also find the margin and padding for each paragraph narrow, causing unwanted paragraph additions. The user suggests improving these features to continue using the product for a fee.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÅ Iterate, improve and grow. Be open to change and adapt to your audience's needs. Remember, building a business is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìà Track your progress and celebrate your wins! Set measurable goals, analyze your metrics, and appreciate your achievements. This is your journey and every small victory matters!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üåü Believe in yourself and your idea. As a solopreneur, self-confidence is crucial. Keep pushing forward, even when things get tough. You've got this!
Summary: The user is a freelance writer and has been using Notion for a year. They are currently working on a book and are looking for a publisher. They are also looking for a design team to work with on their book cover.

User: Not much - sharing is a bit confusing at times but other than than can't think of anything significant.
Summary: User is benefiting from Miro's range of templates, diagrams, and sticky notes which make it easy to share complex ideas visually, resulting in improved collaboration and a more efficient workflow. The User finds Miro to be an incredibly powerful tool for collaborating with teams, due to its easy-to-use interface and real-time collaboration features. Additionally, the platform's extensive range of features are highly customizable, allowing for greater flexibility when working on projects. Users may find the pricing structure of Miro to be expensive for smaller teams or individuals, and the extensive range of features can be overwhelming for new users. However, Miro provides helpful support resources such as video tutorials and a user community to help users get up to speed quickly.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.

It also has issues with writing notes. It doesn't fix spelling mistakes while writing notes. Sometimes it causes a lot of trouble to handle layer ordering. If I want to move one layer in front/back of the other, it takes a lot of effort.
Summary: The user appreciates Figma's FigJam as a virtual whiteboard for sharing team ideas with a wider audience, highlighting its fast, snappy, and easy setup. They also mention its simplicity and ease of sharing with new users. However, they note the recent restrictions on the free tier and limitations in shapes and formatting options.

Text:
User: I'm not a big planner to begin with, probably due to my lack of enjoyment for more mainstream planners like Google calendar and traditional paper planners. Google (while claiming to be user-friendly) had too many tools and GUI's to navigate through which felt overwhelming to me, while still lacking the flexibility I desired. Paper planners I encountered in the store didn't do the job either because they were not formatted exactly how I wanted, and of course a regular old notebook didn't provide the online accessibility I wanted.
Notion is everything you wanted in a planner, and truly helped bring the planning side of me back to reality. It provided helpful templates I could use to give an overall format for what I wanted to write (checklists, boxes, etc.) which were incredibly customizable. The tool is simple yet powerful, without any unnecessary visual effects or special features you are forced to learn. I love that Notion can be accessed on any device via the website or app, and my plans look the exact same in any format without shifting its orientation or completely up-hauling the website layout. I would recommend this to anyone.
Summary: User finds Notion helpful for organizing their daily tasks and planning their week, as it provides templates and customizable tools for organizing their tasks. They appreciate the flexibility and ease of use, and find it helpful for their daily tasks.

Text:
User: We're a hybrid company and working in Product, we often need to have collaborative sessions across teams where some members are remote and some are in person. This is by far the best replacement for old-fashioned in-person whiteboarding with sticky notes, and it's even better because you can save it and easily access it later.
User: It's been conducive to facilitating collaboration on designs, whiteboarding, brainstorming, process reviews, and strategy sessions. Figjam's design makes it easy to use for a wide variety of scenarios. We've used it asynchronously to prep for a discussion as well as simultaneously in-meeting as a way to accomplish in-person whiteboarding-type conversations, especially when some participants are remote.
User: The UI took a little getting used to, and there was a short learning curve to figure out how to access different elements and add them to the page.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's remote collaboration capabilities, allowing colleagues to access and work on the board simultaneously, improving productivity and meeting deadlines. However, they find the default templates and sticky notes to be too small.

User: Everyone: "Use @googledocs it's simple ‚Äì No use @evernote and @NotionHQ it's shared ‚Äì No do @RoamResearch it's serious ‚Äì No, use Apple Notes and Google Keep..."

User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd Obsidian is built on a technology called "Electron".
Electron is just a Chrome browser, that runs like an app on your desktop.
So essentially Obsidian = Snazzy Browser for your notes.
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd This allows us - in theory - to browse any website.
(In practice it works 80% of the time, hence I couldn't get it to work with @tana_inc or @logseq )
While Obsidian does not support that out of the box - with a plugin it's easy. Let's get to it!
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Go to Settings > Community Plugins. Search for "Custom Frames"
Install it. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq In the Obsidian settings there will be now a new entry "Custom Frames" (towards end of your list)
Find the "New Frame" button and click it. A Frame is such a browser window, that we can use to access all of the services.
The new entry will appear in the list above the button. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Configure your Frame
1 Set the URL (<STRICT_LINK>, <STRICT_LINK> or <STRICT_LINK> - copy & paste from Browser)
2 ‚úÖ "open in center" to open the service like a tab (otherwise it's in the sidebar)
3 ‚úÖ "Add Ribbon Icon" to display a side icon. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Specify the icon you want to use.
Go to <STRICT_LINK> and find an icon you like.
Copy paste it's name into the "icon" textfield in previous step. <STRICT_LINK>

Text:
User: How might we collaborate efficiently in a hybrid work environment? 
 
Workshopping within miro means people can participate in workshops remotely, regardless of where they are in the planet. This has also meant that travelling for workshops has become less important - saving the business money.
User: Obviously the pandemic force a lot of us to find new ways to collaborate and connect without being face to face. Miro was clearly ahead of the game in this regard. But even since we're seeing more of each other in the flesh, miro still seems to be adding value with how easy it ease to document workshops, quickly capture ideas, and bring people together to brainstorm.
User: There are very few things to dislike about miro. There are some very minor things like how tables not being incredibly user-friendly, limitations in how you can modify shapes (particularly for the sake of creating wireframes). But all in all, this stuff is nice to have and the fact that you can even do basic wire framing along side everything else that you can do is a win.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's ability to align remote meeting participants and create engaging, self-documenting workshops. The speed and fluidity of the application enhance the facilitator experience. However, the licensing model and board structure can be confusing for infrequent collaborators, and users suggest improving security by including the entire enterprise as users and charging only for power users.

Text: User: I have been using notion for the past two years and it is really helpful. I started using it to organise notes for uni and keep track of my assignments. Initially it is a bit difficult to navigate the service but the more you use it the more efficient you become. You can borrow free templates online if creating your own is difficult! I use notion to track almost everything and even without upgradation the app works reasonably well- you can access the basic things which for a beginner is good enough. Once i figure out how to create templates and deal with the more complex blocks they offer, I will definitely be upgrading to the plus ver
Summary: User has been using Notion for two years and finds it helpful for organizing notes for university and keeping track of assignments. Initially, it is difficult to navigate the service, but with practice, it becomes more efficient. The user appreciates the free templates available online and finds the basic features sufficient for a beginner.

User: Notion evangelist (?) It's an app that was recommended by friends around me while receiving rave reviews, but it's really not good to see the service these days.
If you get paid to do the service, please make it a little straight...

Occasionally, I see this trend on PCs, but many difficult situations occur because they don't support offline mode. I think I should use a basic memo app or go back to Evernote. I don't think the saying that Guguan is a famous building came out of nowhere.
Summary: User is disappointed with Notion, as it is not as good as they expected and has issues with loading documents, especially when offline. They suggest using a basic memo app or going back to Evernote.
