Summary: The product is helping users by providing easier collaboration for remote teams, as well as giving them oversight on work and the ability to document in a single location, which increases visibility and engagement amongst team members. Users appreciate the product's oversight for projects, its intuitive design, and its ability to integrate other apps and features. Users experience fatigue when zooming in and out, and find it difficult to create visuals and diagrams that are interactive. They also find it difficult to copy and paste elements from other sources into Miro, and wish they could consolidate their personal and work accounts.

Text:
User: FigJam impose a collaborative and creative environment. 
It allows teams to work together visually. 
The interactive nature of the tool encourages active participation, engagement, and co-creation. It promotes the sharing of diverse perspectives, sparking creativity and innovation within teams.
User: It offers a range of features like sticky notes, shapes, freehand drawing, etc. 
FigJam is versatile for different types of projects and teams, as it also provides various templates and customisable options.
User: FigJam works great with Figma, but when you need to integrate it with other design tools rather than Figma, it is not easy and more of a manual task. 
It gets really hard to cooperate when using different design tools than Figma.
Summary: User appreciates the flexibility and endless canvas for organizing ideas with colleagues, but finds images to be slow and low-res, and struggles to keep organized between multiple boards.

Text:
User: A diverse and easily accessible whiteboard tool for use during meetings or to collaborate on early-stage ideas. 
Collaborative brain dump before meeting to introduce topics or after meetings to record toughts.
User: Easy to create and share dashboards. 
Tagging features are nice. 
Drag and drop file features work well. 
Live sessions are easy to start and work well as a collaborative space to work during meetings.
User: Integrations with other apps are surface-level. 
There is no baked-in intelligence to the organization of connected objects. 
Large boards become very slow and hard to use.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's flexibility, functionality, and ability to visually communicate inefficiencies to internal clients. They also enjoy the collaboration features. However, they find copying graphics between boards frustrating, as it doesn't always maintain the original formatting.

Text:
User: Continuing the discussion from Dynamic number of nested component instances:
I have components that might include a number of instances of another component, e.g., rows or columns in a table, options in a select/dropdown, etc. To accomplish this, I have to either create a separate variant for each potential number of nested instances, or create the component with the maximum possible number of nested instances and make the instances hide-able. Neither is optimal‚Äîthe first could lead to a crazy number of variants, and the second could result in a large number of hidden layers, which hits performance pretty hard.
It would be great to be able to specify a component instance to be nested in a ‚Äúparent‚Äù component then allow an arbitrary number of the nested ‚Äúchild‚Äù instances in instances of the parent component.
Summary: User discovered a way to transform individual elements in Figma by selecting multiple objects and changing their pixel size in the right panel, similar to Illustrator's "transform each" option.

Text: User: The app itself is so amazing that I'm always thankful to use it very well. However, for users who work on documents and general tasks, poor Bluetooth keyboard connectivity is too fatal. Even if I try to type text from the iPad to the Bluetooth keyboard, the cursor disappears and I can't write at all. So in the end, I have to use a separate laptop, which is such a fatal flaw that makes my personal reason for buying an iPad and starting to use Notion come to nothing. Please improve the Bluetooth keyboard connectivity. By the way, I mainly use Cyclone's K3 model. If only keyboard connectivity were improved, it could be recognized as the best app that could not be expressed even with five stars. The fact that I can't use an external keyboard is so decisive for me.
Summary: User is satisfied with the app but has issues with Bluetooth keyboard connectivity, making it difficult to use on the iPad. They suggest improving the keyboard connectivity to make the app more useful for their needs.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.

Text:
User: Hi, I believe I‚Äôve exhausted all the existing help articles on this.
I‚Äôm having a hard time with something that should be very basic. I have 25 or so screens, the ONLY interaction between them is that the user should be able to click and/or press the arrow key to navigate LINEARLY between them.
Sometimes it works (especially if I go slowly, it works every time). But sometimes it doesn‚Äôt, sometimes it inexplicably jumps through sections (pretty much only happens if I press the arrow keys quickly). It appears that if I click through it goes linearly every time without skipping screens. So the problem is only with the arrow keys (which I can‚Äôt disable so I need to understand the behavior before handing off to my client).
I‚Äôve adjusted all the artboards. The desired order is Row 1 Left to Right, Row 2 Left to Right (as described in the documentation). All rows have the exact same Y coordinate. All columns have the exact same X coordinate.
I‚Äôve spent hours on this already and this is really basic behavior so I‚Äôm not sure why it‚Äôs so hard, I want it to act like powerpoint in presentation mode.
Any help is appreciated. I can‚Äôt really share the prototype because I‚Äôm on NDA.
User: Or up vote the solution here‚Ä¶
 
 
 
 Remove auto creating flow starting points Share an idea
 
 
 I love the new feature that allows multiple prototypes per page. One issue I‚Äôm having with it, is it assumes I want everything to be a new flow starting point each time I don‚Äôt link something from the first flow starting page. 
It has a very linear mindset. When I work/prototype I tend to work on a section, then link it back and that creates many flow starting points on accident and I have to delete them. 
It‚Äôd be nice if either - it only created the first one, and doesn‚Äôt assume you want many o‚Ä¶
Summary: User appreciates the ability to use images in new and cool ways.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.

User: This, on @figma makes no sense. Who decided rgba is the default color notation for css/web? Today we have so many color spaces available, but designers are stuck with hex/rgb. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @equinusocio @figma We've hit this a lot with our new design system. We use a lot of modern CSS but need fallbacks to represent things in Figma.
In the past browsers didn't keep up and couldn't accurately replicate designer's work. Now it's the design tools that are lagging.
User: @equinusocio @figma It's not a surprise when new features hit browsers - it's often gone through years of spec work and "Intent to ship" - I really wish @figma would step up here and be ready to ship things like oklch/oklab, color-mix, etc along side browsers

User: Hi all,
After the most recent update of Figma - Pushed a couple of days ago, prototypes using Figma‚Äôs nested component prototyping have been affected. This has been cross checked on web links / alternative machines.
This has new overwrites that aren‚Äôt included and are causing very concerning issues, especially on components that use auto layouts. This, ultimately, means if we hadn‚Äôt complete a round of user testing a couple of weeks prior we would have some serious issues.
Is anyone else getting anything similar?
Thanks,
Alex
User: I have the same issue, and it is not still resolved. Was it fixed with the weekend update for everybody else as well?
User: Yeah, seems to be fixed for me now. I‚Äôve named everything back to how it was and it‚Äôs still working.
User: Thanks man, works for me after renaming. Doesn‚Äôt work after reseting name back. Still better than nothing, but it is a real pain as thats part of our design system and i should provide some guideance how to use that component

Text:
User: I'm not a big planner to begin with, probably due to my lack of enjoyment for more mainstream planners like Google calendar and traditional paper planners. Google (while claiming to be user-friendly) had too many tools and GUI's to navigate through which felt overwhelming to me, while still lacking the flexibility I desired. Paper planners I encountered in the store didn't do the job either because they were not formatted exactly how I wanted, and of course a regular old notebook didn't provide the online accessibility I wanted.
Notion is everything you wanted in a planner, and truly helped bring the planning side of me back to reality. It provided helpful templates I could use to give an overall format for what I wanted to write (checklists, boxes, etc.) which were incredibly customizable. The tool is simple yet powerful, without any unnecessary visual effects or special features you are forced to learn. I love that Notion can be accessed on any device via the website or app, and my plans look the exact same in any format without shifting its orientation or completely up-hauling the website layout. I would recommend this to anyone.
Summary: User finds Notion helpful for organizing their daily tasks and planning their week, as it provides templates and customizable tools for organizing their tasks. They appreciate the flexibility and ease of use, and find it helpful for their daily tasks.

Repository - bringing multimedia assets related to a single project into one space

User: As a UX researcher, I've been using Miro for years. It helped me collaborate remotely before the pandemic forced everyone to go remote. I've used it for project management, research synthesis, collaboration and feedback and even lightweight design. The templates help save time when putting together something like a Gantt or Kanban board. An absolute must for remove workshops: love the timer, background musing, voting, 'Follow me' mode. Very easy to learn.
User: The UI has gotten a bit busy, with controls in all 4 corners of the screen. I supposed it's expected for a tool that does so many jobs.
Summary: User appreciates the ease of collaboration and sharing information with remote whiteboarding sessions facilitated by FigJam, and mentions that non-designers have started to adopt it in their workflows. They also suggest adding more visual options to the platform to create more customized and visually exciting files.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!

User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd Obsidian is built on a technology called "Electron".
Electron is just a Chrome browser, that runs like an app on your desktop.
So essentially Obsidian = Snazzy Browser for your notes.
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd This allows us - in theory - to browse any website.
(In practice it works 80% of the time, hence I couldn't get it to work with @tana_inc or @logseq )
While Obsidian does not support that out of the box - with a plugin it's easy. Let's get to it!
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Go to Settings > Community Plugins. Search for "Custom Frames"
Install it. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq In the Obsidian settings there will be now a new entry "Custom Frames" (towards end of your list)
Find the "New Frame" button and click it. A Frame is such a browser window, that we can use to access all of the services.
The new entry will appear in the list above the button. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Configure your Frame
1 Set the URL (<STRICT_LINK>, <STRICT_LINK> or <STRICT_LINK> - copy & paste from Browser)
2 ‚úÖ "open in center" to open the service like a tab (otherwise it's in the sidebar)
3 ‚úÖ "Add Ribbon Icon" to display a side icon. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Specify the icon you want to use.
Go to <STRICT_LINK> and find an icon you like.
Copy paste it's name into the "icon" textfield in previous step. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq RESTART OBSIDIAN
Your new ribbon icon should now appear on the left.
You will have to log in to Google/Apple/Evernote/... the first time. But then it will remember you. (Just like in a browser)
On the top right you find a few buttons, to reload the page. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Summary:
‚ñ∫ Download "Custom Frames" plugin
‚ñ∫ Add frames to any website, as Obsidian is technically a browser.
‚ñ∫ This technique works with ANY website. So you can integrate google calendar, facebook or a todo app into obsidian!
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Obsidian is THE note-taking app to rule them all. I focus on helping Academics & Knowledge Workers, to leverage its capacities to the max. If you want to propel your academic career, join my seminar this week and become an "Effortless Academic"!
<STRICT_LINK>
User: @Artifexx @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq @SaveToNotion #Thread #Study

Text:
User: Hi all, I am working on a Figma plugin that needs to import style from our team library. Through research I think the way is to first use Figma REST API to get the keys of styles from our library file, and the use figma.importStyleByKeyAsync() to import the style. However, the issue is, this requires me to put my Access token in the plugin, and I don‚Äôt want to. Is there a way for plugin to authenticate when making REST API calls on behalf of the person who uses the plugin?
Or are there any other easier ways to import/access styles from team library file in plugin? Thanks a lot!!!
User: You have several ways:
Users will create their own personal access tokens, which will be inserted into the input field of your plugin.
Users will open the necessary library files, run the plugin there to get the necessary keys, return to another file to continue working.
Hardcode the keys in the plugin.
3.1. Or add these keys to, for example, a JSON file that you or anyone else can keep updating as needed.

User: Hi, I believe I‚Äôve exhausted all the existing help articles on this.
I‚Äôm having a hard time with something that should be very basic. I have 25 or so screens, the ONLY interaction between them is that the user should be able to click and/or press the arrow key to navigate LINEARLY between them.
Sometimes it works (especially if I go slowly, it works every time). But sometimes it doesn‚Äôt, sometimes it inexplicably jumps through sections (pretty much only happens if I press the arrow keys quickly). It appears that if I click through it goes linearly every time without skipping screens. So the problem is only with the arrow keys (which I can‚Äôt disable so I need to understand the behavior before handing off to my client).
I‚Äôve adjusted all the artboards. The desired order is Row 1 Left to Right, Row 2 Left to Right (as described in the documentation). All rows have the exact same Y coordinate. All columns have the exact same X coordinate.
I‚Äôve spent hours on this already and this is really basic behavior so I‚Äôm not sure why it‚Äôs so hard, I want it to act like powerpoint in presentation mode.
Any help is appreciated. I can‚Äôt really share the prototype because I‚Äôm on NDA.
User: Or up vote the solution here‚Ä¶
 
 
 
 Remove auto creating flow starting points Share an idea
 
 
 I love the new feature that allows multiple prototypes per page. One issue I‚Äôm having with it, is it assumes I want everything to be a new flow starting point each time I don‚Äôt link something from the first flow starting page. 
It has a very linear mindset. When I work/prototype I tend to work on a section, then link it back and that creates many flow starting points on accident and I have to delete them. 
It‚Äôd be nice if either - it only created the first one, and doesn‚Äôt assume you want many o‚Ä¶

Text: User: I have been using notion for the past two years and it is really helpful. I started using it to organise notes for uni and keep track of my assignments. Initially it is a bit difficult to navigate the service but the more you use it the more efficient you become. You can borrow free templates online if creating your own is difficult! I use notion to track almost everything and even without upgradation the app works reasonably well- you can access the basic things which for a beginner is good enough. Once i figure out how to create templates and deal with the more complex blocks they offer, I will definitely be upgrading to the plus ver
Summary: User has been using Notion for two years and finds it helpful for organizing notes for university and keeping track of assignments. Initially, it is difficult to navigate the service, but with practice, it becomes more efficient. The user appreciates the free templates available online and finds the basic features sufficient for a beginner.

However, they experience performance issues with large boards or many simultaneous users and feel that customization options can be restrictive.

Text: User: I have been using notion for the past two years and it is really helpful. I started using it to organise notes for uni and keep track of my assignments. Initially it is a bit difficult to navigate the service but the more you use it the more efficient you become. You can borrow free templates online if creating your own is difficult! I use notion to track almost everything and even without upgradation the app works reasonably well- you can access the basic things which for a beginner is good enough. Once i figure out how to create templates and deal with the more complex blocks they offer, I will definitely be upgrading to the plus ver
Summary: User has been using Notion for two years and finds it helpful for organizing notes for university and keeping track of assignments. Initially, it is difficult to navigate the service, but with practice, it becomes more efficient. The user appreciates the free templates available online and finds the basic features sufficient for a beginner.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.

Text:
User: Hi!
Turning off ‚Äúsnap to pixel grid‚Äù in a Figma Design file no longer changes snapping behavior when dragging frames around.
Whether this feature is turned on or off, a dragged frame still snaps to each pixel, no matter how zoomed-in. Note that some other objects (e.g., vector objects) still respect this setting. It‚Äôs just an issue with frames, components, and component instances. Note that If I group the frame, I then can drag the group to any sub-pixel location.
I‚Äôve restarted my machine, restarted Figma, checked for updates, reloaded tabs, tried it in other design files. Tried it in the client, in Chrome, and in Safari. Same problem.
Can anyone else replicate this?
User: Uff‚Ä¶ This is a huge issue for creating illustrations and configuring logos, vector graphics, etc. Please fix this.
Summary: Users find the zoom speed in Figma on Windows laptops frustratingly high when using the trackpad, making it difficult to use on the go. They are seeking a solution or workaround to control the zoom speed, and it seems the issue may have been resolved for some users.

Text:
User: MIRO helps me manage a project schedule with complex deliverables, timeline, swimlane owners, and key cross-functional dependencies. It also helps with basic product roadmap and innovation planning. The visual appeal is also helpful as it can serve as a presentation board for senior management presentations.
User: MIRO is an ideal tool for facilitating collaboration across teams or large groups. I use it with my teams for a variety of applications, including planning project schedules, brainstorming ideas, mapping out solutions and process flow diagrams. It is highly flexible, allowing the user to define the structure and content. I really like the ease of use and the infinite space, which allows you to constantly be adding to existing boards. There are many existing templates that help provide a good starting point for collaboration.
User: One of the challenges that we've seen is integration with other software. I'd like to see a more seamless integration with MS Excel--for instance, the ability to capture live Excel spreadsheets in MIRO that are auto-updates as the underlying Excel sheet changes.
Summary: The user appreciates the collaboration features of Miro, which allow team members to work together regardless of location. They also appreciate the digital whiteboard, which allows teams to capture ideas, organize information, and make decisions in real-time. The user finds the tool easy to use and appreciates the zoom in/zoom out feature. However, they find it challenging to use from mobile internet due to the high-speed internet requirement.

Text:
User: I use Miro for mind maps, team whiteboard sessions, sprint and product retrospectives, collaborative wireframing with User Experience designers, and could go on with this list. It has application with a number of product management tasks.
User: I use Miro for a long list of important product management activities. It has a nice set of wireframing tools and is easy for someone who wants to sketch out ideas without using advanced design tools like Figma of Invision. I also use it to collaborate with stakeholders within the company when framing problems. The team there regularly makes product enhancements that make the tool even better.
User: The organizational structure of the tool leaves a bit to be desired. This may be user error more than anything but, sometimes, after creating several different boards on a similar topic, it's hard to organize them into a folder structure that makes it easy to find the board I'm looking for.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its easy navigation, customizable templates, and visually appealing interface. They find it effective for client meetings and project planning, and believe it fulfills its intended purpose without any significant weaknesses.

Text:
User: I'm not a big planner to begin with, probably due to my lack of enjoyment for more mainstream planners like Google calendar and traditional paper planners. Google (while claiming to be user-friendly) had too many tools and GUI's to navigate through which felt overwhelming to me, while still lacking the flexibility I desired. Paper planners I encountered in the store didn't do the job either because they were not formatted exactly how I wanted, and of course a regular old notebook didn't provide the online accessibility I wanted.
Notion is everything you wanted in a planner, and truly helped bring the planning side of me back to reality. It provided helpful templates I could use to give an overall format for what I wanted to write (checklists, boxes, etc.) which were incredibly customizable. The tool is simple yet powerful, without any unnecessary visual effects or special features you are forced to learn. I love that Notion can be accessed on any device via the website or app, and my plans look the exact same in any format without shifting its orientation or completely up-hauling the website layout. I would recommend this to anyone.
Summary: User finds Notion helpful for organizing their daily tasks and planning their week, as it provides templates and customizable tools for organizing their tasks. They appreciate the flexibility and ease of use, and find it helpful for their daily tasks.

Text:
User: Miro has the power to aggregate what has been shared among multiple tools. In addition, it has the potential to allow multiple people to work at the same time without any problems, and it has been used in seminars and training sessions, and has been very popular. In the training that I participate in, training using miro is increasing, and it is very useful to visualize the result of the discussion in a short time.
User: Miro is easier to use than an actual whiteboard. In particular, it's easy to attach, write, move, and connect sticky notes, and it automatically corrects the connection lines, so you can use it more efficiently than an actual whiteboard. So you can focus on the discussion. Also, miro is great for sharing information you create online, ensuring that the same image information is conveyed. As a comparison to other similar tools, it's nice to have reaction features, icons, and formatting that you can't use up.
User: The disadvantage of miro is that the access can be quite slow depending on the board. When you first open a board with a lot of information on it, you often have to wait a few 10 seconds. I hope that this problem will be solved by devising means such as image processing centered on the area where the display priority is being determined. Also, if you just use it, you don't have a chance to see new or useful functions, so I think it would be good if you were shown it by a pop-up (This feature may already exist and you may have turned it off yourself, but it is true that it does not appear at this time.).
Summary: The user appreciates Figma for its ease of use in remote and hybrid teams, allowing for asynchronous problem-solving and accessible designs. However, they find the flow charting feature challenging when referencing other boards.

Text:
User: It is extremely difficult to use compared to the PC version for the following reasons.
„ÉªHaving to press the completion button in the upper right corner every time you perform an operation is troublesome. Place the button in a place where it's a little easier to press (like the bottom), or make it possible to complete the operation by simply scrolling
„ÉªThe display of access history is in the way. I want them to be able to hide it in settings.
Summary: User finds the product extremely difficult to use compared to the PC version, as they have to press the completion button in the upper right corner every time they perform an operation, and the access history is in the way. They suggest placing the button in a more accessible location or making it possible to complete the operation by simply scrolling.

- Clickable carousels

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.

Text: User: I have been using notion for the past two years and it is really helpful. I started using it to organise notes for uni and keep track of my assignments. Initially it is a bit difficult to navigate the service but the more you use it the more efficient you become. You can borrow free templates online if creating your own is difficult! I use notion to track almost everything and even without upgradation the app works reasonably well- you can access the basic things which for a beginner is good enough. Once i figure out how to create templates and deal with the more complex blocks they offer, I will definitely be upgrading to the plus ver
Summary: User has been using Notion for two years and finds it helpful for organizing notes for university and keeping track of assignments. Initially, it is difficult to navigate the service, but with practice, it becomes more efficient. The user appreciates the free templates available online and finds the basic features sufficient for a beginner.

Text:
User: 10 tools I use every week as a product manager:
User: 1. @asana 
This is our tool of choice when it comes to organizing work throughout the company.
Simple but powerful, it does everything we need to keep our teams organized and our work visible.
User: 2. @MiroHQ 
I've been using Miro for everything lately: product briefs, data analyses, brainstorming, mockups. 
It's a tool that can do a ton of things well, and helps make visuals much easier to consume vs. a document.
User: 3. Looker
We've used Looker for several years, and it's our go-to spot for building reports and dashboards.
Our core team dashboard and pricing/conversion dashboards both live here, and I check each daily.
User: 4. @Amplitude_HQ 
For product analytics, we use Amplitude. Looker gives me high-level business metrics; Amplitude gives me the details.
We use this for understanding the user behavior behind the metrics.
User: 5. @CrazyEgg & @hotjar 
Two tools that do similar things: we use one for our website and one for our app.
These give us even more qualitative data behind our metrics, with things like heat maps and screen recordings.
User: 6. @SlackHQ 
I barely use email any more, and while the Slack overload is real, it does enable fast async communication among our teams, wherever we are.
It's also great for consolidating notifications from other tools (Asana, Google Docs, etc.) if you set up the integrations.
User: 7. @Officevibe 
Our HR team implemented this tool, and as PM, it gives me a bunch of metrics about how my team is doing.
It gives me some data backing for how the team is feeling, and shows me when I might need to spend time on morale.
User: 8. @figma 
Miro is great for lo-fi prototypes and brainstorming, but at some point it moves to Figma.
This is where we build prototypes for user testing, comment on designs, and ultimately deliver the final spec to developers.
Summary: User's design for an ad poster for Orijin Nigeria was featured on the list of awesome works on JoinTabulio, thanks to @joinTabulio for spotlighting it.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÅ Iterate, improve and grow. Be open to change and adapt to your audience's needs. Remember, building a business is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìà Track your progress and celebrate your wins! Set measurable goals, analyze your metrics, and appreciate your achievements. This is your journey and every small victory matters!
Summary: The user is a freelance writer and has been using Notion for a year. They are currently working on a book and are looking for a publisher. They are also looking for a designer to help with the cover.

Text:
User: Another problem that Miro solves is the challenge of sharing complex ideas in a simple way. Miro's range of templates, diagrams, and sticky notes make it easy to share ideas visually, which can be especially helpful for projects that require a lot of detail or complexity. This has allowed me to communicate my ideas more effectively with my team members, resulting in better collaboration and a more efficient workflow.
User: I have found Miro to be an incredibly powerful tool for collaborating with teams. One of the things I like best about Miro is how easy it is to use. The interface is intuitive and user-friendly, making it simple to get started even for those who are not particularly tech-savvy. 
The real-time collaboration features in Miro are also incredibly helpful. Multiple team members can work on a board simultaneously, which helps to streamline the collaborative process and ensure that everyone is on the same page. Additionally, the platform's extensive range of features, such as templates, sticky notes, and diagrams, are highly customizable, allowing for greater flexibility when working on projects.
User: One thing that I have found to be a drawback of Miro is its pricing structure. While the platform offers a free plan, its more advanced features are only available with paid plans, which may be expensive for smaller teams or individuals. Additionally, the platform's extensive range of features can be overwhelming for new users, and it may take some time to learn how to use everything effectively. However, Miro's support resources, including video tutorials and a user community, are quite helpful in getting up to speed quickly.
Summary: The user loves FigJam for its ease of use and prefers it over multiple apps for conceptualizing ideas and storyboards. They have not used any other whiteboarding app and cannot identify any limitations.

Text:
User: Miro solves two huge problems for me. 
 
1. Remote working and having collaborative sessions with other team members. Before I found Miro, having these sessions was incredibly hard 
2. When you write on a whiteboard, at some stage it gets rubbed off. Miro you can have endless whiteboards that you never need to delete
User: Miro is incredibly helpful for a number of reasons. The best way to look at it is like a whiteboard with all the relevant tools, online. You can use it for brainstorming sessions, mapping customer journeys, comparing notes and heaps more. It feels like I have only just scraped the surface with what is possible on Miro.
User: Honestly, there aren't many downsides to using Miro. The hardest part is probably getting use to it and understanding what you should use for certain things. Maybe some more tutorials would be helpful.
Summary: The user finds Figma helpful for design creation, review, and QA purposes, appreciating its easy-to-understand UI and simple commenting system. However, they find sharing content challenging, as it requires sharing the entire board, leading to confusion and difficulty in accessing specific content.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.

Text:
User: Miro helps me create a mindmap for a product, share it with clients and other stakeholders, get feedback, and work collaboratively. Miro also allows me to make the initial sketch for a product to give the clients a basic flow of the product so we can solve the problems before the development and keep the product consistent; this also helps in efficiency and reducing costs.
User: The upside of Miro is brainstorming can be done collaboratively with all the stakeholders, including clients; this helps in coming up with solutions quickly and even testing out the ideas in the initial stages of development.
User: Miro is a good app overall, but it can sometimes be overwhelming and cluttered. Miro cannot be used offline. Navigating on a larger gets a little tedious and occasionally inaccurate. lags at times.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's collaborative features for gaining consensus among product team members and its ability to replace conference room whiteboards. However, they face challenges with importing Excel tables and HTML content and desire more robust editing options for post-it note styles.

When I won +$2500 here.

So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÅ Iterate, improve and grow. Be open to change and adapt to your audience's needs. Remember, building a business is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìà Track your progress and celebrate your wins! Set measurable goals, analyze your metrics, and appreciate your achievements. This is your journey and every small victory matters!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üåü Believe in yourself and your idea. As a solopreneur, self-confidence is crucial. Keep pushing forward, even when things get tough. You've got this!
Summary: The user is a freelance writer and has been using Notion for a year. They are currently working on a book and are looking for a publisher. They are also looking for a design team to work with on their book cover.

Summary: Flux is an open-source power tool for interacting with LLMs, allowing users to generate multiple completions per prompt in a tree structure and explore the best ones in parallel. It offers a variety of creative responses, tests different prompts with shared context, and identifies model uncertainties. Flux also features keyboard shortcuts, system message editing, autosaving, and direct use of the OpenAI API. The creators are open to collaboration and are working on an LLM collaboration tool using Ceramic Network's ComposeDB and Flux, similar to Figma for prompt design.

Text:
User: We want to start using versioning in our projects and we are trying to figure out the best way to do it.
The approach that makes more sense to us is to create a new branch on each file for the new version.
Our issue is that we have team members working on each version (1 and 2) but we can‚Äôt create a new feature branch for the version 2 branch (we don‚Äôt have this issue for version 1 because that is the main branch).
Our question is if does exist an official way to work with different versions in the same file in order to handle versioning or if there is a better way to do this.
Example of what we need
Button v1 branch (main)
a new feature for Button v1 (a new branch from the main branch)
Button v2 branch (version 2 branch)
a new feature for Button v2 (a new branch from version 2 branch)
The second question is how to handle major, minor, and patch updates into Figma (following semantic versioning definition)
Our idea is to handle major changes with branches, and minor/patches with version history. What do you think?
There is a recommended way to handle versioning?
Summary: User experiences frequent errors when opening files in team projects and struggles to return to them after closing. The issue was resolved with a solution provided by another user.

User: Notion itself is powerful, but the app must get a low score! However, all functions cannot be operated on the app. For example, basic operations such as moving positions of some objects on the app are not possible! The interface usually gets stuck and is difficult to operate, and the compatibility is poor. If you don't want to do a more complete edit on the app, you'll die! Very poor experience of use! It's best to use it on a computer!
Also, sharing content from another place to Notion is very difficult to use. After sharing, you have to go back to Notion to do a bunch of operations and organization. This kind of basic requirement should be designed to be easy to use! I don't even understand that I shared a Youtube video to Notion. The result was to set up a page in Notion. Then the title was: What's the point of the URL?! It can't be designed. Can you create a page with the title of the video or go to an existing page and then create an embedded video??
Summary: User finds Notion powerful but finds the app difficult to use due to its poor interface and lack of basic functions. They also find it difficult to share content from other apps and find the title of the shared video to be confusing. The user suggests improving the app's interface and functionality, as well as creating a page with the title of the shared video.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÅ Iterate, improve and grow. Be open to change and adapt to your audience's needs. Remember, building a business is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìà Track your progress and celebrate your wins! Set measurable goals, analyze your metrics, and appreciate your achievements. This is your journey and every small victory matters!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üåü Believe in yourself and your idea. As a solopreneur, self-confidence is crucial. Keep pushing forward, even when things get tough. You've got this!
Summary: The user is a freelance writer and has been using Notion for a year. They are currently working on a book and are looking for a publisher. They are also looking for a design team to work with on their book cover.

Text:
User: It's the go-to design tool in our team. It responds to all wireframing, prototyping, and design requirements and facilitates team collaboration. It also comes with Figjam, and eliminates need for other whiteboarding tools.
User: It's easy to get started with Figma, and its robust community means there are tons of resources and plugins to inspire and help speed up your design process (and there are some incredible plugins out there)!
User: There isn't much to dislike, but there are a few inconveniences. First, everything is online so you need a strong internet connection, especially when dealing with large files. Second, the way plugins are handled can feel a bit clunky (you have to look for it, save/run it, and it opens as a separate window - wish there was a way to anchor it). Third, it might just be me but I always get confused navigating within the community section... but again these are just minor inconveniences and the pros far outweigh the cons.
Summary: User appreciates Figma's seamless screen creation and cloud collaboration features, but requests an increase in the number of pages available in the free version.

Text:
User: It allows me to put all the pieces of my project in one place, so nothing gets lost. When you have an evolving project with research and numerous iterations it helps to be able to see all the info in one place and makes it easier for others to understand the full picture. 
 
I also use miro to share out work and do critiques. It is easy to have collaborators follow me on the board while I am presenting. I will generally share my screen while presenting, but it can be hard to see small details so having others in the board helps with this. There are comment and sticky notes available for peers to leave feedback too.
User: The board is endless and I can fill it with as much content as I want. There is a timer and you can set yourself to be followed around the board which makes critiques easier. It is extremely easy to add arrow connections. Overall, it's simple and easy to use.
User: Miro has cool features that are somewhat hidden so I didn't realize they existed for awhile. Because boards can fill up easily it helps to share a link for a frame directly and it can be done, but it's hidden behind a meatball menu. There are stickers, which come in handy, but are hidden behind a plus on the sidebar.
Summary: User loves Miro for its simplicity, ease of use, and self-explanatory shortcuts for brainstorming and sharing ideas. They appreciate the ability to sketch and create retro presentations, but find it difficult to zoom in and out and have multiple users on the same presentation spot.

Text:
User: Autolayout with hug content on width or height should resize to zero (or whatever the applied padding is) when all content is hidden. Now when all contents are hidden it remains as the dimensions of the last visible item it had. Anyone have a workaround or know if there is a way to avoid this bug?
User: I am also experiencing this. The container with auto layout has its height set to ‚ÄúHug contents‚Äù with no vertical spacing, and no vertical padding, and child element heights are also ‚ÄúHug contents‚Äù.
However, the issue seems to be from what occurs when you hide layers because their height automatically changes to ‚ÄúFixed‚Äù. BUT even just deleting the layers at once still leaves the container at its previous height despite still being set to ‚ÄúHug contents‚Äù.
Something‚Äôs up with this.
Summary: User prefers layers sorted from top to bottom and suggests a settings option for this, as well as automatic layer renaming based on content changes, such as text updates.

Text: User: I have been using notion for the past two years and it is really helpful. I started using it to organise notes for uni and keep track of my assignments. Summary: User has been using Notion for two years and finds it helpful for organizing notes for university and keeping track of assignments. We use Miro to exchange ideas, visualize data in user-friendly formats and plan some processes.

User: The categorization of the boards is complicated. I am still looking for a way to sort them out that I like. However, the performance and features keep me sticking with this software.

Text: User: Don‚Äôt subscribe through an in app purchase. Their product naming is misleading. The Personal Pro is their free offering with limited ai requests (20) but through an in app purchase they will gladly sell you the same product for a $47 annual subscription. Just like the free product it stops working at 20 ai requests. I‚Äôd say that this product without the ai feature is crap. You can do better with any number of free products on the market. Google docs, etc. And the product without the ai is free anyways so why offer an ‚Äúupgrade‚Äù link when all you are doing is paying for something they offer for free. I‚Äôm angry but glad I subscribed through Apple- there is a chance I can get a refund. The ai is pretty good but I am wary at the shady deal they tried to pull over me. Who know who else made the same mistake?
Summary: User is unhappy with the product name and misleading subscription pricing, as the free version is limited to 20 requests and stops working after 20. They also mention that the ai feature is not as good as other free products, and the upgrade link is misleading. They are considering a refund and are wary of other users making the same mistake.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÅ Iterate, improve and grow. Be open to change and adapt to your audience's needs. Remember, building a business is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìà Track your progress and celebrate your wins! Set measurable goals, analyze your metrics, and appreciate your achievements. This is your journey and every small victory matters!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üåü Believe in yourself and your idea. As a solopreneur, self-confidence is crucial. Keep pushing forward, even when things get tough. You've got this!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÑ Found this thread helpful? Share it with fellow indie makers and solopreneurs who could use these tips! Let's support each other on our solo business journeys!<STRICT_LINK>
Summary: The user is a freelance writer and has been using Notion for a few months. They are currently working on a project and are looking for a designer to join their team.

User: I want to love this app so badly, I spent truly all day playing around trying to make it work for me. I watched so many tutorials. But the fact of the matter is its a bad app for iPad. I can‚Äôt afford a real computer so I have to use an iPad instead, and I‚Äôm not alone in this, so I do feel that Notion should be prioritizing this more than they are (and it seems this has been ongoing according to Reddit).
Some issues I‚Äôve faced on iPad:
-Nearly impossible to click and drag blocks successfully and smoothly.
-You can‚Äôt select multiple blocks at the same time.
-I‚Äôve read about and really wanted to use the ‚Äúrepeat‚Äù feature, which is nowhere to be found on the iPad.
Notion marketing team, if you‚Äôre reading this: PLEASE test your app on an iPad and fix it, I‚Äôm desperate to love your app!!!!
Summary: User loves the app but finds it difficult to use on iPad due to issues with clicking and dragging blocks, inability to select multiple blocks, and the lack of the "repeat" feature. They suggest prioritizing the app's development for iPad users and request that the Notion marketing team test the app on an iPad.

Summary: The user appreciates the ability to organize their project in one place and share it with collaborators, as well as the ability to add comments and sticky notes. Text: User: I love to use the desktop or web apps, so I had high hopes for the iPad version...but no, it's just not even usable. For example, to add a title, normally you use a slash...here, you use the slash, you see the menu with options pop up (you can't continue to type what you need), and then it disappears. Eventually you see that there's a completely different menu which pops up at the bottom, why? Then this menu is also buggy, and doesn't always appear when needed. Also the move page option doesn't seem to work, and there's no way to archive, and so on. The app comes with prefilled project templates with example data that you can't delete. You can't be productive, it's just frustrating.
Summary: User finds the iPad version of Notion unusable due to its lack of usability and bugs, as well as the inability to archive and delete project templates. They suggest using the desktop or web apps instead.
