Text:
User: FigJam allows me and my team to quickly and easily make low-fidelity wireframes and conceptual designs as well as collect our findings from our user interviews and other Discovery activities.
User: I love the ability to ideate and diagram in FigJam and then copy it to Figma to use as a reference and modify as necessary. It's really great to use them in tandem. I also find the shapes and arrows easy to use and connect. The stickers are a fun feature as well. 
 
The audio chat in Figjam and Figma is clutch. My team will typically meet in there instead of scheduling a Teams meeting. It's a great way to hop on review a design or ask questions about a specific thing. 
 
I also really like the option to give anyone access for 24 hours. This is great for collaborating with people that are not within the company.
User: There's nothing I don't like about FigJam. I don't feel like there is anything missing from the application.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma for enabling remote ideation sessions and asynchronous collaboration. They like the infinite space, autosave, PDF export, and its intuitiveness for occasional participants. However, they face issues with limited text box characters, undo functionality, presentation uploads losing resolution, lack of GIF support, inability to upload videos directly, and incompatibility with Visio maps.

Text: User: Don‚Äôt subscribe through an in app purchase. Their product naming is misleading. The Personal Pro is their free offering with limited ai requests (20) but through an in app purchase they will gladly sell you the same product for a $47 annual subscription. Just like the free product it stops working at 20 ai requests. I‚Äôd say that this product without the ai feature is crap. You can do better with any number of free products on the market. Google docs, etc. And the product without the ai is free anyways so why offer an ‚Äúupgrade‚Äù link when all you are doing is paying for something they offer for free. I‚Äôm angry but glad I subscribed through Apple- there is a chance I can get a refund. The ai is pretty good but I am wary at the shady deal they tried to pull over me. Who know who else made the same mistake?
Summary: User is unhappy with the product name and misleading subscription pricing, as the free version is limited to 20 requests and stops working after 20. They also mention that the ai feature is not as good as other free products, and the upgrade link is misleading. They are considering a refund and are wary of other users making the same mistake.

Text: User: I have been using notion for the past two years and it is really helpful. I started using it to organise notes for uni and keep track of my assignments. Initially it is a bit difficult to navigate the service but the more you use it the more efficient you become. You can borrow free templates online if creating your own is difficult! I use notion to track almost everything and even without upgradation the app works reasonably well- you can access the basic things which for a beginner is good enough. Once i figure out how to create templates and deal with the more complex blocks they offer, I will definitely be upgrading to the plus ver
Summary: User has been using Notion for two years and finds it helpful for organizing notes for university and keeping track of assignments. Initially, it is difficult to navigate the service, but with practice, it becomes more efficient. The user appreciates the free templates available online and finds the basic features sufficient for a beginner.

Text:
User: I'm not a big planner to begin with, probably due to my lack of enjoyment for more mainstream planners like Google calendar and traditional paper planners. Google (while claiming to be user-friendly) had too many tools and GUI's to navigate through which felt overwhelming to me, while still lacking the flexibility I desired. Paper planners I encountered in the store didn't do the job either because they were not formatted exactly how I wanted, and of course a regular old notebook didn't provide the online accessibility I wanted.
Notion is everything you wanted in a planner, and truly helped bring the planning side of me back to reality. It provided helpful templates I could use to give an overall format for what I wanted to write (checklists, boxes, etc.) which were incredibly customizable. The tool is simple yet powerful, without any unnecessary visual effects or special features you are forced to learn. I love that Notion can be accessed on any device via the website or app, and my plans look the exact same in any format without shifting its orientation or completely up-hauling the website layout. I would recommend this to anyone.
Summary: User finds Notion helpful for organizing their daily tasks and planning their week, as it provides templates and customizable tools for organizing their tasks. They appreciate the flexibility and ease of use, and find it helpful for their daily tasks.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: The user is enjoying the new features in Arc, including the split view, sidebar, and the ability to pin folders. They are also impressed with the iOS app, which allows them to open links in specific spaces. However, they are concerned about the lack of a mobile app and the lack of a way to tell apps to open links in specific spaces.

Text:
User: Hi there, I am currently laying the foundations for a Design Language System. At the same time another team is working on the first of a series of Apps. My intention is to take the components that they create for that first app and then add them to the design system, so we can re-use elements for all the future Apps
The DLS and the the first App will be created as two separate design files within the same project. My hope was that at various intervals I would be able to copy and paste content from the App into the DLS then publish the library from the DLS and get the other team to use the library swap feature to swap their local components with those from the DLS published library.
But my initial tests lead me to believe that this isn‚Äôt possible. It seems that you can only use library swap on two externally published libraries rather than an external library (the DLS) and a local library (the App). Is this the case?
If so, what is the suggested workflow in this situation?
Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated. Many thanks
User: This topic was automatically closed after 30 days. New replies are no longer allowed.

Text: User: There are too many restrictions when using it on an iPad or iPhone compared to using it on a desktop. User praises the Solopreneur No-Code Toolkit, which includes Figma, Notion, Canva, and Typedream, as useful tools for solopreneurs.

Text:
User: Today I want to give some insights into the TOOLS that we use at our agency that works with startups from around the world including Silicon Valley.
(Giveaway at the end) <STRICT_LINK>
User: 2/12 First up, we use @NotionHQ . It's our hub for everything. Tasks, deadlines, management ‚Äì it's all there. It works like a charm to keep everything organised, especially when working when a team it‚Äôs nice, since everyone knows what‚Äôs where.
User: 3/12 Next, Slack. We use this mainly for internal communication with the team and for communication with a few clients. In the beginning we wanted to use Slack 100% for clients communication, but some clients just don‚Äôt like it, and we don‚Äôt want to force them haha.
User: 4/12 We also use Monday, it's our CRM where we track leads and conversions, basically keeping our clients in the loop. We used to do this in Notion, but it was hard to use which made it less motivating to keep it up to date.
User: 5/12 @zapier is our go-to for automation. It takes care of all the repeat stuff, so we have more time to be creative. Nothing special, but is saves a lot of time.
User: 6/12 For crafting copy we use @OpenAI's ChatGPT. Before GPT released we were actually using a tool called Jasper a year ago, it was around 100USD a month and delivered 30% of the results GPT offers for free, a real game changer.
User: 7/12 @webflow is the platform we use to built our website with, which integrates seamlessly with all our other tools through Zapier.
User: 8/12 For designs, we're all about @figma, from UI designs to logos, it's our go-to for making visuals.
Summary: User shares their plan to write a case study on their personal website, showcasing their design ideas and implementation process. They mention using Figma, Webflow, and custom JS for designing and developing the website, which took about two months to complete.

Text:
User: Serving as a one-stop-shop for designing and planning an intensive leadership course; delivering the course itself (various group and individual activities will be performed in a Miro board); team collaboration and content visualization.
User: Nearly limitless toolset coupled with intuitive functionality; plays nicely with links, pasted and imported resources, and videos; allows you to dump, organize and map all the various pieces of a vast (or simple) project; offers amazing opportunities for team / group collaboration; insanely useful tool not just for planning but for presentation as well - can also easily be leveraged as a (FUN!) teaching tool. New features and integrations are continually added, so even if something isn't possible or easy now, you can bet it will be added soon.
User: While intuitive, there can be a bit of a learning curve for new users (for instance, learning how to pull oneself across the board versus grabbing and moving board items). Board owners must be thoughtful in locking or hiding items they don't want moved or deleted ahead of time to ensure visitors don't inadvertently mess up your masterpiece. There are still some hard-to-explain quirks - for instance, some URL links (for whatever reason) show up as just links when pasted, whereas others show up as a summary snapshot of the resource.
Summary: The user appreciates the ability to create Agile retrospectives, root cause analysis, and visualizing a road map, as well as the ability to interactively edit tasks in a schedule. They also appreciate the flexibility of the Miro template for Fishbone diagrams, but wish for a user-defined zoom percentage.

Text:
User: Up your gradient game! 
Learn how to create this folded gradient effect with @figma, in just a few easy steps ‚Äî no plugins needed.
Ready? Let‚Äôs dive in üëá
#sponsored <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 1
Create a new artboard and add a rectangle with a grey fill <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 2 
Go into vector edit mode and select 2 anchor points. Manipulate those till you get an angle you like <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 3 
Repeat the first 2 steps and make sure to connect each begin of a fold with the end points of the previous one <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 4
Finish your composition, make sure to create artboard copies for different iterations! <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 5 
Time for some color! Create a linear gradient going from light to dark, and copy & paste the style to your vectors. (OPT+CMD+C -> OPT+CMD+V) 
Tip: Use more than 2 color stops in your gradient for a unique look! <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 6 
Nice! Now we just have to change the gradient angles for every other vector to create more realistic lighting <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 7 
To take your gradient fold to the next level, introduce some extra color combinations! <STRICT_LINK>
User: Bonus Step 
You can try to go for a top and bottom gradient effect as shown below... <STRICT_LINK>
User: Okay one more bonus step. 
You can even try to split up a larger gradient in multiple stops to create an effect like shown below. 
No matter what you do, make sure to experiment and have fun! <STRICT_LINK>
User: Are you trying out this technique? Make sure to share it by tagging @figma and @FonsMans. See you at the next one!
‚ú® Follow me @FonsMans for more
üîÅ Like/Retweet this thread so more people can see it!
Summary: User is optimistic about AI's ability to amplify human work, live, and create, and is looking forward to the conversation at @Figma's Config.

User: So I‚Äôm trying to embed video files with alpha channels for a presentation. I ran a test where I included a webm file over some live text. I previewed it as a presentation and it worked perfectly. I sent it to my manager to reveiw and when he looked at it the alpha channel was replaced w/ a black background and a white box around that content that‚Äôd previously been over transparency.
Is Figma re-encoding my file? If so it‚Äôs doing it wrong. If not, why is the video changing after a period of time?
User: I was told by a Figma rep that they don‚Äôt plan on fixing this because safari doesn‚Äôt support webm v9 w/ transparency. This seems silly because that‚Äôs only on mobile. Also the issue is with figma‚Äôs re-compression of uploaded webm. it works fine initially but breaks after they come in and incorrectly re-compress properly encoded files. I‚Äôd prefer my files Not work on safari mobile rather than have them look wrong everywhere.
Summary: User faced an issue with a dropdown menu in Figma, where it rapidly opened and closed during preview. Another user suggested that the issue might be due to the prototype getting stuck between opening and closing the overlay, and recommended using interactive components instead of the Overlay feature to fix the problem.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÅ Iterate, improve and grow. Be open to change and adapt to your audience's needs. Remember, building a business is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìà Track your progress and celebrate your wins! Set measurable goals, analyze your metrics, and appreciate your achievements. This is your journey and every small victory matters!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üåü Believe in yourself and your idea. As a solopreneur, self-confidence is crucial. Keep pushing forward, even when things get tough. You've got this!
Summary: The user is a freelance writer and has been using Notion for a year. They are currently working on a book and are looking for a publisher. They are also looking for a design team to work with on their book cover.

User: I sometimes wish the drawings tools were a bit more robust - they seems to be geared toward flow chart style communication. I'd like to be able to sketch free form shapes or have a larger shape library.
Summary: The user appreciates Figma and FigJam as a one-stop shop for design and mind mapping, praising its ease of use, stability, and reasonable cost. However, they suggest improving the sharing process, as team account users can currently add editors and charge licenses to the organization, with restrictions requiring an enterprise plan upgrade and increased cost.

Text:
User: Documenting information in diagrams/maps helps the team visualize complex information architecture and align on foundations. 
Sketching ideas in low fidelity increases our time to value at early design stages by allowing us to validate concepts before investing in high-fidelity visualizations. Having a space to collaborate on these low-fidelity designs makes the validation process more efficient and consolidates the thinking. 
Using FigJam to share information with less design-savvy coworkers offers a friendly way to collect and organize inspiration or audits.
User: FigJam makes it easy for me to sketch ideas, map information in diagrams, and collaborate with others. There's just enough design functionality to bring concepts to life without getting lost in the details. Additional tools make workshops or brainstorming sessions fun and easy for my non-designer colleagues to pick up. I love having access to community-made templates and graphics for inspiration.
User: I wish participants could be invited to edit files without having a licensed seat. I have run interactive workshops with participants who do not regularly use the tool, and getting folks proper access in these cases is a bit tricky. In cases where I have colleagues who need temporary access to files, I use open sessions, but need to reopen them each time the colleague requires edit access.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro as a common platform for collaboration and visualization, which helps in daily presentations and organizing Agile events. However, they suggest improving the pen functionality for a smoother writing experience and propose the addition of a touchpad for more natural drawing

Text:
User: Our team likes to use Figjam primarily because it's provided by Figma. We use Figma for design anyway, so its handy to have Figma provide an internal whiteboarding/collaboration tool without us having to create account & learn another platform.
User: What I like about Figjam is that it's easy to use and provides some templates (with instructions) so that teams can get onboarded quickly and start collaborating. I've used Figjam with other designers and also with non-design/tech team members, and we've benefitted tremendously from using Figjam as a fun collaboration tool.
User: While I like that Figjam provides basic tools for brainstorming and real-time collaboration, I sometimes find it can be too limiting. I wish there were more customization options related to shapes, colours, and fonts, so that my teammates and I can explore crude wireframes that are just a little more detailed than the rounded rectangles and other shapes that Figjam allows. When the project moves to that stage, I end up moving to regular Figma and using the comment functionality there, or, if it's difficult to manage access, create shapes in a Figma file then copy/paste into Figjam which can be tedious.
Summary: Users appreciate Figjam for its ability to organize ideas in an aesthetically pleasing way and facilitate collaboration with colleagues. They enjoy the customization tools and design features, but would like to see some Figma functions, such as saving an image, integrated into Figjam.

Text:
User: It solves the same problem as other whiteboard app does. The fact it comes as part of Figma is a huge plus. I might consider using something else if it was a big add-on or wasn't part of the main platform. There are better apps, but the fact that this baked ina s part of Figma is the biggest reason I use it. It's great that it allows me to quickly spin up a board and hammer out visual concepts quickly and I'd happily use this to create UR artifacts, but it has some drawbacks and I wouldn't be able to facilitate some activities.
User: Figjam is a great tool that fulfills a lot of the functionality you get in more advanced whiteboard apps and does more or less a good job of it. The ability to deep-link to elements in a board, and make sections and post-its, is fine and works pretty well.
User: There could be more functionality to format and resize post-its. It'd also be really helpful, for the facilitation of workshop activities, to be able to show and hide sections. this would ideally be on a user or for users or user groups. More mechanics like this, which allows groups of participants and facilitators to work together, would have a positive impact on running workshop activity withing the Figma platform and in FigJam.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma for its collaborative features, time-saving templates, and ease of creating visually appealing charts and flows. They also enjoy using Miro for various agency tasks, such as information architecture creation and user experience workshops, due to its user-friendly interface. However, some users experience performance issues on low-end devices when using Chrome browser for large boards, suggesting potential room for performance optimization.

User: It replaced physical whiteboards for discovery and brainstorming sessions. It also works as an excellent ice-breaker and teambuilding tool to have everyone active during meetings or learning sessions.
User: For those who miss physical whiteboards and post-its this is the solution to easily (and virtually) visualize projects and organize brainstorming, project management and workflow visualization. It's very friendly, intuitive and compatible with other tools.
User: Some toolboxes usually overlap important information, and sharing options are not that easy to understand and use, mainly with external (not frequent) users.
Summary: Users find Miro to be an effective collaboration tool that helps run meetings smoothly, reduces manual work, and saves costs. They appreciate its user-friendly interface, available templates, sharing capabilities, and affordability. Miro has positively impacted their workplace, and they have no significant dislikes about the tool.

Text: User: I have been using notion for the past two years and it is really helpful. I started using it to organise notes for uni and keep track of my assignments. Initially it is a bit difficult to navigate the service but the more you use it the more efficient you become. You can borrow free templates online if creating your own is difficult! I use notion to track almost everything and even without upgradation the app works reasonably well- you can access the basic things which for a beginner is good enough. Once i figure out how to create templates and deal with the more complex blocks they offer, I will definitely be upgrading to the plus ver
Summary: User has been using Notion for two years and finds it helpful for organizing notes for university and keeping track of assignments. Initially, it is difficult to navigate the service, but with practice, it becomes more efficient. The user appreciates the free templates available online and finds the basic features sufficient for a beginner.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÅ Iterate, improve and grow. Be open to change and adapt to your audience's needs. Remember, building a business is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìà Track your progress and celebrate your wins! Set measurable goals, analyze your metrics, and appreciate your achievements. This is your journey and every small victory matters!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üåü Believe in yourself and your idea. As a solopreneur, self-confidence is crucial. Keep pushing forward, even when things get tough. You've got this!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÑ Found this thread helpful? Share it with fellow indie makers and solopreneurs who could use these tips! Let's support each other on our solo business journeys!<STRICT_LINK>
Summary: The user is a freelance writer and has been using Notion for a few months. They are currently working on a project and are looking for a designer to join their team.

Text: User: I‚Äôve been using Notion for a couple of years and it‚Äôs one of the easiest and most comprehensive applications to use for note-taking on MacBooks. Recently I‚Äôve switched to an iPad and the functionality has drastically deteriorated in my user experience which is concerning as the iPad is usually touted as a functional productivity device, especially to students for notes. The app often glitches, the toolbar at the bottom for editing font often disappears while working on multiple tabs, sometimes font colours don‚Äôt show up on screen even after multiple tries. There‚Äôs difficulty in moving blocks of text around on the screen for re-ordering sometimes, especially when working with stage manager in the smallest pre-set window.
Summary: User experienced issues with Notion on their iPad, such as glitches, disappearing toolbar, and difficulty in moving blocks of text around. They mentioned that the app is not as functional as it was on their MacBooks.
